revision.text:
'''Ablade''' is both a surname and a given name. Notable people with the name include:
*[[Seth Ablade]] (born 1983), Ghanaian footballer
*[[Ablade Glover]] (born 1934), Ghanaian artist and educator. *[[Ablade Kumah]] (born 1970), Ghanaian footballer *[[Ablade Morgan]] (born 1980), Ghanaian footballer
{{given name|type=both}} {{surname}}

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox sportsperson| | name = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | fullname = | nicknames = | nationality = {{USA}} | club = | collegeteam = | sport = Soccer / Cerebral palsy soccer | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|5|29}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|m=1.72}} | weight = {{convert|155|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | paralympics = [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] | medaltemplates= {{MedalSport | Paralympic 7-a-side football}} {{MedalCompetition|2010 Americas Championship}} {{MedalSilver | Team | Men's }} | updated = 18 June 2016 }} '''Adam Ballou''' (born May 29, 1992) is an American soccer player and cerebral palsy football player. Ballou has cerebral palsy as a result of an intrauterine stroke, he was diagnosed at six months old. He attended [[James Madison University]], graduating in 2015. He started playing soccer when he was 3 years old, played rec, advanced and travel. He also played on his high school varsity team, and was team captain his junior and senior years.
Ballou has been a consistent member of the United States Paralympic National Team since being invited to train with them in March 2007 as a 14-years-old. He has competed at the CP Football World Championships in 2009, 2011, and 2015. He has also represented the United States at the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] in London. His best performance with the team was a second-place finish at the 2010 Americas Championship.
== Personal == Ballou was born on May 29, 1992 in Virginia Beach, Virginia <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://lacancha.net/2012/08/31/u-s-paralympic-national-team-paralympic-games-riverbank-arena-london-england-sept-1-9-2012/|title=U.S. Paralympic National Team – Paralympic Games Riverbank Arena; London, England Sept. 1-9, 2012|last=Robbins|first=Gerard|date=August 31, 2012|work=La Cancha|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2016/03/03/16/08/160303-pnt-paralympic-team-heads-to-chula-vista-for-training-camp|title=U.S. PARALYMPIC TEAM HEADS TO CHULA VISTA FOR TRAINING CAMP|last=|first=|date=March 3, 2016|website=U.S. Soccer|publisher=U.S. Soccer|access-date=May 15, 2016}}</ref> and has three sisters.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/panamgames/2015/08/09/bittersweet-win-for-canada-over-us-in-parapan-am-games-7-a-side-football.html|title=Bittersweet win for Canada over U.S. in Parapan Am Games 7-a-side football|last=Otis|first=Daniel|date=August 9, 2015|work=The Toronto Star|access-date=May 16, 2016|via=}}</ref> Ballou was diagnosed with [[cerebral palsy]] when he was six months old, after he had a pediatric stroke.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://pilotonline.com/news/local/three-local-players-going-to-paralympics-in-london/article_7429d3a1-d85b-5353-ab36-c45eb2cb323c.html|title=Three local players going to Paralympics in London|last=Macaulay|first=David|date=August 20, 2012|work=The Virginian Pilot|access-date=May 16, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.coastalvirginiamag.com/September-2012/Against-the-Odds/?cparticle=2&siarticle=1|title=Against the Odds|last=Carey|first=Anne|date=September 2012|work=Coastal Virginia Magazine|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.hercampus.com/school/jmu/prince-william-wasn-t-only-duke-london-summer-meet-adam-ballou|title=Prince William wasn’t the only Duke in London this summer: Meet Adam Ballou|last=Peale|first=Melissa|date=September 21, 2012|work=Her Campus|access-date=May 21, 2012|via=}}</ref> As a result of the stroke, when he was an infant, doctors told his parents that he might live his life as a vegetable. The stroke had resulted in him acquiring cerebral palsy and having limited limb functionality on his left side, making it substantially weaker than his right side.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> To address these physical issues, Ballou had regular physical therapy as a result until he was around a 13-year-old.<ref name=":5" />
Ballou attended [[Norfolk Christian High School]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]], graduating from there in 2011.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://www.maxpreps.com/athlete/adam-ballou/O-Hhw_TtEeKZ5AAmVebBJg/default.htm|title=Adam Ballou|last=|first=|date=2011|website=MaxPreps|publisher=CBS Interactive|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> He went on from there to study International Affairs and Spanish at [[James Madison University]]. He graduated in 2015, with a minors in business as well as Latin American and Caribbean Studies.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.whsv.com/content/sports/US-Paralympians-visit-JMU--376787721.html|title=US Paralympians visit JMU to promote movement|last=DeGuzman|first=David|date=April 22, 2016|work=WHSV|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.jmu.edu/kinesiology/features/paralympic.html|title=Paralympic Athletes Lead Kin 100 Skill Lab Experiences|last=Creative Services|first=|date=April 27, 2016|work=|publisher=James Madison University|access-date=June 18, 2016|via=}}</ref> While attending university, he took the spring semester of 2012 off so he could train with the US national team ahead of the London Games.<ref name=":5" /> He also studied abroad, spending a semester in [[Salamanca|Salamanca, Spain]].<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.teamusa.org/para-soccer/athletes/Adam-Ballou|title=Adam Ballou|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Team USA|publisher=United States Olympic Committee|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> In 2014, he completed an internship for U.S. State Department at the Embassy in Madrid in 2014 as part of his studies.<ref name=":10" /> He has continued to be involved with the university following his graduation. In April 2016, he gave a workshop on Paralympic sport at his alma mater's [[Godwin Hall]] in [[Harrisonburg, Virginia|Harrisonburg]] <ref name=":1" />
Ballou speaks Spanish and English.<ref name=":9" /> He is 5 foot 8 and weighs 155 pounds.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" />
== Sports == Ballou started playing soccer when he was a 3-year-old, playing for a team that included his sister and which his father was the coach of.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /> He was able to compete in sports after he had a tendon transfer on his left foot.<ref name=":4" /> Many people in his life encouraged him to participate in sports. Because of his disability, he trained harder on that side of the body and sometimes feels he performs better on that side as a result.<ref name=":4" /> He played varsity soccer for Norfolk Christian High School.<ref name=":11" /> In 2012, his soccer coaches were Jay Hoffman and Mike Haas.<ref name=":9" />
== Cerebral palsy football == Ballou is a CP7 footballer and a regular fixture on the [[United States national cerebral palsy football team|US National Paralympic Team]],<ref name=":10" /><ref name=rostersalou/> where he plays in the midfield.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theoriginalwinger.com/2012/08/video-u-s-paralympic-soccer-team-ready-for-london-games/|title=Video :: U.S. Paralympic Soccer Team Ready For London Games|last=Dunny|first=|date=August 28, 2012|work=The Original Winger|access-date=June 18, 2016|via=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923153442/http://theoriginalwinger.com/2012/08/video-u-s-paralympic-soccer-team-ready-for-london-games/|archive-date=2016-09-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Ballou started playing CP football in 2007 after getting invited to train with the national team in March. At the time, he was a 14-years-old. He came to the attention of national selectors after the head coach of the Virginia Beach Mariners asked his coach if he knew of any players with cerebral palsy and his coach replied with Ballou's name and contact details. Because of the rules for CP football, he was not able to earn his first national team cap until he was a 16-years-old.<ref name=":5" />
The United States tried but failed to qualify for the [[2008 Summer Paralympics]]. If they had been successful, Ballou would likely have made the roster.<ref name=":5" /> He continued his national team career, and was part of the US team that finished 11th at the 2009 World Championships.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" /> He continued to get national team calls ups, and was with the US team that finished second at the 2010 Americas Championship.<ref name=":9" /> The following year, he participated in the 2011 CPISRA World Championships with the national team.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eastcountymagazine.org/la-mesa-athlete-goes-dutch-play-japan-june-19th|title=LA Mesa Athlete Goes Dutch to Play Japan on June 19th|last=Logan|first=Ron|date=June 2011|work=East County Magazine|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://www.teamusa.org/US-Paralympics/Features/2015/June/16/US-Paralympic-National-Team-heads-to-cerebral-palsy-soccer-world-champs|title=U.S. Paralympic National Team heads to cerebral palsy football world championships|last=U.S. Soccer|first=|date=June 16, 2015|work=U.S. Soccer|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> An eighth-place finish at this tournament qualified the United States for the London Games.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/03/17/13/09/us-paralympic-national-team-head-coach-jay-hoffman-selects-roster-for-paralympic-games|title=U.S. PARALYMPIC NATIONAL TEAM HEAD COACH JAY HOFFMAN SELECTS 12-PLAYER ROSTER FOR 2012 PARALYMPIC GAMES|last=|first=|date=July 26, 2016|work=US Soccer|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref>
Ballou spent a lot of time preparing for the [[Football 7-a-side at the 2012 Summer Paralympics|2012 Summer Paralympics]]. When not with the national team, he trained at the [[Virginia Beach Sportsplex]].<ref name=":4" /> Having taken a semester off to prepare for the Games, he spent a lot of time in 2012 training with the national team in [[Chula Vista, California]]<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> and was formally chosen by national team head coach Jay Hoffman to be on the London bound national team.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://lacancha.net/2012/08/31/u-s-paralympic-national-team-paralympic-games-riverbank-arena-london-england-sept-1-9-2012/|title=U.S. Paralympic National Team – Paralympic Games Riverbank Arena; London, England Sept. 1-9, 2012|last=Robbins|first=Gerard|date=August 31, 2012|work=La Cancha|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestarnews.com/sports/let-the-games-begin-london-calls-to-chula-vista-olympic-training-center-athletes/|title=Let the Games begin! London calls to Chula Vista Olympic Training Center athletes|last=Brents|first=Phillip|date=July 27, 2012|work=The Star-News|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestarnews.com/sports/paralympic-athletes-set-the-standard-at-chula-vista-olympic-training-center/|title=Paralympic athletes set the standard at Chula Vista Olympic Training Center|last=Brents|first=Phillip|date=|work=The Star News|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref>
The 2012 Games were his first,<ref name=":4"/><ref name=":13" /> as the national team had not qualified for Beijing.<ref name=":5" /> Ballou was one of seven US Paralympians from Virginia competing in London,<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.blazesports.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/London_2012_Paralympic_Games_Media_Guide1.pdf|title=Team USA Media Guide|last=|first=|date=2012|website=Blaze Sports|publisher=United States Olympic Committee|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> and his family flew to London to watch him play.<ref name=":5" /> Lots of people came to watch the Games, with 80,000 people showing up to the opening ceremonies and 25,000 people showing up to watch his team play Great Britain.<ref name=":5" /> The United States was drawn in Group B with Ukraine, Great Britain and Brazil.<ref name=":8" /> The Americans did not win a single game, losing all 5 matches they played in.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=http://norfolkchristian.org/document.doc?id=452&erid=0|title=Reaching your goals|last=Posch|first=Brianna|date=February 2013|work=Echo 2.0|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> After the Games when he returned to the USA, he was with the team when they met US President Barack Obama.<ref name=":12" /> His participation in London gave him the resolve to try to make the roster for the [[2016 Summer Paralympics|2016 Games]].<ref name=":5" />
In April 2014, Ballou was invited to participate in a week long national team training camp at the Olympic Training Center in Chula Vista, California. The camp was being held in preparation for the 7-a-side Football Ciutat de Barcelona in June of that year.<ref name="barcacamp">{{Cite news|url=http://www.socceramerica.com/article/57604/us-paralympic-national-team-roster.html|title=U.S. Paralympic national team roster|last=|first=|date=April 22, 2014|work=Soccer America Daily|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref> In March 2015, he was part of the 14 man roster that participated in the [[Póvoa de Varzim|Povoa de Varzim, Portugal]] hosted Footie 7 – Povoa 2015 tournament.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://rushsoccer.com/en/86-front-page-stories/301-keith-johnson-us-paralympic-national-team|title=KEITH JOHNSON – US PARALYMPIC NATIONAL TEAM|last=|first=|date=September 1, 2015|website=Rush Soccer|publisher=|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> The competition was a warmup for the World Championships that were held in England in June 2015.<ref name=":6" />
Ballou was named to the US side for the 2015 Cerebral Palsy World Championships in England in June 2015.<ref name=":7" /> Ballou came off the bench to substitute in for Michael Moore in the team's 10 - 0 loss to England.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/disability/2015/jun/england-v-usa-match-report-200615|title=England booked an intriguing final Cerebral Palsy World Championships fixture against the Republic of Ireland, after a commanding 10-0 victory against USA.|last=Reid|first=Jamie|date=June 26, 2015|website=The FA|publisher=|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> He started in the team's 2 - 1 win against Scotland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soccerwire.com/news/nt/international-men/u-s-paralympic-national-team-completes-comeback-for-2-1-win-over-scotland/|title=U.S. Paralympic National Team completes comeback for 2-1 win over Scotland|last=U.S. Soccer|first=|date=June 20, 2015|work=Soccer Wire|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> In the 7th/8th placement match, Argentine goalkeeper Gustavo Nahuelquin was red carded for kicking Ballou. Teammate David Garza then scored on the penalty kick. Ballou scored his own goal later in the game against Argentina. The United States won the game 4 - 1.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/sports/San-Diego-Native-Leads-Team-USA-To-2016-Olympics-310403511.html|title=San Diego Native Leads Team USA To 2016 Olympics|last=Schildhouse|first=Becki|date=June 27, 2015|work=NBC San Diego|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1028326/wonder-strikes-propel-england-to-fifth-place-finish-at-cerebral-palsy-football-world-championships|title=Wonder strikes propel England to fifth place finish at Cerebral Palsy Football World Championships|last=Butler|first=Nick|date=June 27, 2015|work=InsideTheGames|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> This performance qualified the United States for the 2016 Summer Paralympics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/2apublishing/docs/pos_mag_aug_sep11|title=Russia edge Ukraine to retain CP World Championships|last=Rimmer|first=Peter|date=September 2015|work=Possibility|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> [[File:IFCPF Pre Paralympic Tournament Salou 2016 37.jpg|thumb|Adam Ballou, right, warms up with a teammate in preparation for the US's game against Brazil at a tournament in Salou in 2016.]] Again, Ballou was called to participate on the national team after being named to the 14 man squad for the [[2015 Parapan American Games]] in Toronto. There, the United States played Canada, Venezuela, Argentina and Brazil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soccernation.com/uspnt-roster-for-the-2015-parapan-american-games/|title=USPNT ROSTER FOR THE 2015 PARAPAN AMERICAN GAMES|last=|first=|date=August 6, 2015|work=Soccer Nation|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://d1686qux8loigy.cloudfront.net/pan-am-games-story/5790877-bittersweet-win-for-canada-over-u-s-in-parapan-am-games-7-a-side-football/|title=Bittersweet win for Canada over U.S. in Parapan Am Games 7-a-side football|last=Otis|first=Daniel|date=August 9, 2016|work=Norfolk News|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> He played in the team's match against Canada.<ref name=":2" /> He spent parts of 2015 and 2016 training full-time in preparation for the Rio Games.<ref name=":13" />
Later that year, Ballou was nominated for the 2015 U.S. Soccer’s Young Disabled Player of the Year alongside teammate [[Kevin Hensley (Paralympic footballer)|Kevin Hensley]] and US national amputee football team players [[Nicolai Calabria]] and [[Noah Grove]]. He lost out Hensley in getting the honor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soccerwire.com/news/nt/nominees-for-u-s-soccer-young-male-female-and-disabled-player-of-the-year/|title=Nominees for U.S. Soccer Young Male, Female and Disabled Player of the Year|last=|first=|date=December 12, 2015|work=Soccer Wire|access-date=May 16, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bigapplesoccer.com/teams/redbulls2.php?article_id=43496|title=YOUNG PLAYER OF THE YEAR|last=|first=|date=December 11, 2015|work=Big Apple Soccer|access-date=May 16, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2015/12/11/new-york-red-bulls-matt-miazga-nominated-us-soccer-young-male-player-year|title=New York Red Bulls' Matt Miazga nominated for US Soccer Young Male Player of the Year|last=|first=|date=December 11, 2015|work=MLS Soccer|access-date=May 16, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thesportscampus.com/2015121148725/fifa-news/nominees-announced-for-2015-usa-soccer-young-male-young-female-and-disabled-player-of-the-year |title=Nominees announced for 2015 USA Soccer Young Male, Young Female and Disabled Player of the Year |last= |first= |date=December 12, 2015 |work=The Sport Campus |access-date=May 21, 2016 |via= }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
2016 saw Ballou again getting invitations to play with the US Paralympic Team. He participated national team training camp in Chula Vista, California in early March 2016.<ref name=":0" /> Following that, Ballou was part of the US that took part in the 2016 Pre Paralympic Tournament in [[Salou]], [[Spain]].<ref name="rostersalou">{{Cite web|url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/ec86d3_605daf1002c543fbb466a4d9298f8bf5.pdf|title=United States — Roster|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref> The United States finished 6th after beating Argentina in one placement match 4 - 3 and losing to Ireland 4 - 1. The goals scored in the match against Argentina were the first the USA scored in the tournament, before putting up one more in their match against Ireland.<ref name="USAIreland">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/match/171|title=Ireland — USA|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/match/170|title=USA — Argentina|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/match/169|title=Argentina — Ireland|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref> Ballou scored an own goal in the USA's game against Ireland.<ref name="USAIreland" /> The tournament featured 7 of the 8 teams participating in Rio. It was the last major preparation event ahead of the Rio Games for all teams participating.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/international-tournament-schedule|title=Schedule|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{Portal|United States|Association football}} {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=August 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox AFL biography | name = Andrew Embley | image = | alt = | caption = | fullname = Andrew Embley | nickname = Embers | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1981|6|27}} | birth_place = [[Perth]], [[Western Australia]] | death_date = | death_place = | originalteam = Bassendean JFC | draftpick = 57th pick, [[1998 AFL Draft|1998 National Draft]] | height = 189 cm | weight = 91 kg | position = Wingman | statsend = 2013 | years1 = 1999–2013 | club1 = {{AFL WC}} | games_goals1 = 250 (216) | nationalyears1 = 2004 | nationalteam1 = [[Australian International rules football team|Australia]] | nationalgames_goals1 = 2 (0) | careerhighlights = * [[AFL Rising Star]] nominee 2000 * {{AFL WC}} premiership side 2006 * [[Norm Smith Medal]] 2006 }}
'''Andrew Embley''' (born 27 June 1981) is a former [[Australian rules football]]er who played with the [[West Coast Eagles]] in the [[Australian Football League]] (AFL). He is known for winning the [[Norm Smith Medal]] as the best player in the [[2006 AFL Grand Final]].
Embley was born in [[Perth]] and began his career with {{WAFL SD}} in the [[West Australian Football League]] (WAFL). He was recruited by West Coast with the 57th pick in the [[1998 AFL Draft|1998 National Draft]]. Embley made his debut in the first match of the [[1999 AFL season|1999 season]], and was an [[AFL Rising Star]] nominee the following year. In 2004, he represented [[Australian International rules football team|Australia]] in the [[International Rules Series]]. Embley was one of West Coast's vice-captains between 2004 and 2006, and played a key part in West Coast's victory over {{AFL Syd}} in the 2006 AFL Grand Final. He was awarded the [[Norm Smith Medal]] as the best player on the ground. Embley retired at the end of the [[2013 AFL season|2013 season]] after 250 games for the club. He also kicked 216 goals, finishing second in [[List of West Coast Eagles leading goalkickers|the club's goal-kicking]] in 2003 and 2006.
==Early life and family== Embley was born in [[Perth]], [[Western Australia]], to parents Maurice and Anne Embley. His father is of [[Anglo-Burmese people|Anglo-Burmese]] and [[Spanish people|Spanish]] descent and was born in [[Yangon|Rangoon]], emigrating to Australia in 1964 with his family after the [[1962 Burmese coup d'état|1962 Burmese coup]] and settling in [[Victoria Park, Western Australia|Victoria Park]]. His mother, originally from [[Ballarat]], is of [[Italian Australian|Italian]] and [[Irish Australian|Irish]] descent. His father played reserves football for [[Perth Football Club|Perth]], and also represented Western Australia in the 1973 national junior athletic championships in [[Melbourne]].<ref>[http://www.afl.com.au/tabid/208/default.aspx?newsid=26502 Embley's Journey] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006200410/http://www.afl.com.au/tabid/208/default.aspx?newsid=26502 |date=6 October 2012 }} - AFL.com.au. Published 9 June 2006. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref> Embley's brothers James (17 games) and Michael (8 games) have both played football for the [[Swan Districts Football Club]].<ref>[http://www.waflonline.com.au/players/view/1204 James Embley] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110329181457/http://www.waflonline.com.au/players/view/1204 |date=29 March 2011 }} - WAFLOnline player profile.</ref><ref>[http://www.waflonline.com.au/players/view/822 Michael Embley] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121230195107/http://www.waflonline.com.au/players/view/822 |date=30 December 2012 }} - WAFLOnline player profile.</ref> Michael Embley also was rookie-listed by West Coast for three seasons from 2004 to 2006, but did not play a senior game for the club.<ref>[http://www.eaglesflyinghigh.com/players/index.php?id=621 Michael Embley] – EaglesFlyingHigh. Retrieved 3 March 2012.</ref> Along with his brothers, Embley attended [[Trinity College, Perth|Trinity College]] in [[East Perth, Western Australia|East Perth]], and played junior football for the Bassendean Junior Football Club. He made his WAFL debut for [[Swan Districts]] in 1998,<ref name="waflprofile">[http://www.waflonline.com.au/players/view/395 Andrew Embley] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110329180928/http://www.waflonline.com.au/players/view/395 |date=29 March 2011 }} – WAFLOnline player profile. Retrieved 3 March 2012.</ref> and was recruited by the West Coast Eagles with the 57th pick overall in the [[1998 AFL Draft#National Draft|1998 National Draft]].
==Football career== [[File:Andrew Embley cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Embley marking the ball against Sydney in the [[2005 AFL Grand Final]]]] Embley made his debut for West Coast in the first round of the [[1999 AFL season|1999 season]], a [[Western Derby]] against {{AFL Fre}}, gathering nine disposals and taking three marks. He played nine games in total for the season, as well as 13 WAFL games for {{WAFL Cla}} as part of an [[Reserves affiliations of Australian Football League clubs|affiliation]] with West Coast which lasted until 2000. Embley played 28 games over the next two seasons, mainly as a [[Half-forward line|half-forward flanker]], scoring 29 goals including three four-goal hauls.<ref name="afltables">[http://afltables.com/afl/stats/players/A/Andrew_Embley.html Andrew Embley] - AFLTables.</ref> He was nominated for the [[2000 AFL Rising Star]] for his efforts against {{AFL PA}} in [[2000 AFL season#Round 14|round 14]].<ref>[http://www.westcoasteagles.com.au/players/playerprofile/andrewembley/tabid/7302/playerid/14562/category/senior/season/2011/selected/bio/default.aspx Andrew Embley] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603151240/http://www.westcoasteagles.com.au/players/playerprofile/andrewembley/tabid/7302/playerid/14562/category/senior/season/2011/selected/bio/default.aspx |date=3 June 2011 }} - WestCoastEagles.com.au. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref>
With [[John Worsfold]] having replaced [[Ken Judge]] as coach of the club prior to the start of the [[2002 AFL season|2002 season]], Embley established himself as a regular part of the Eagles' line-up over the next two seasons, playing in losing elimination finals in both the [[2003 AFL season|2003]] and [[2004 AFL season|2004 finals series]]. He kicked 31 goals in 2003 to finish second in the Eagles' goalkicking behind [[Phil Matera]] (62 goals). A 25-disposal, four-goal game against {{AFL Col}} in round eight, 2003, earnt him three [[Brownlow Medal]] votes, the first of his career. Embley was named vice-captain of West Coast for the 2004 season, and also represented [[Australian International rules football team|Australia]] in that year's [[International Rules Series]].<ref>[http://www.eaglesflyinghigh.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=1479&start=0 International Rules squad named] - EaglesFlyingHigh. Published 5 October 2004. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref> Embley played 18 games for the Eagles in the [[2005 AFL season|2005]] season, including all of the Eagles' finals and the [[2005 AFL Grand Final|Grand Final loss]] to {{AFL Syd}}. He played 23 out of a possible 24 games in the Eagles' [[2006 AFL season|2006 season]], playing mainly across the [[half-forward line]] and [[centre line (football)|wings]]. Embley also kicked 31 goals for the season to be the club's second leading-goalkicker behind [[Quinten Lynch]] (65 goals).<ref>{{cite book|last=Lovett|first=Michael|title=AFL Record Guide to Season 2007|publisher=AFL Publishing|location=Melbourne|year=2007|isbn=978-0-9758362-7-9|page=292}}</ref> Despite injuries late in the season, Embley played a key role in the team's successful [[2006 AFL finals series|final series]]. He averaged 26 possessions and kicked five goals across the Eagles' three finals matches, despite playing the semi-final against the {{AFL WB}} with a paralysed vocal chord.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/silence-golden-as-embley-back/story-e6frf33l-1111112208287 |title=Silence golden as Embley back |work=[[The Australian]] |date=14 September 2006 |accessdate=28 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62YRrjdlq?url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/silence-golden-as-embley-back/story-e6frf33l-1111112208287 |archivedate=19 October 2011 |first=Courtney |last=Walsh |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> He took a game-saving mark in the preliminary final against {{AFL Ade}} in a game the Eagles won by 10 points. He was awarded the 2006 [[Norm Smith Medal]] as the [[Best on ground|best-on-ground]] player in the Eagles' [[2006 AFL Grand Final|Grand Final win]] over {{AFL Syd}} for his 26-disposal, two-goal effort.<ref>[http://www.westcoasteagles.com.au/tabid/7155/default.aspx?newsid=97548 Embley commits to improve] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321224702/http://www.westcoasteagles.com.au/tabid/7155/default.aspx?newsid=97548 |date=21 March 2012 }} - WestCoastEagles.com.au. Published 5 July 2010. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://blogs.news.com.au/heraldsun/sport/index.php/heraldsun/comments/did_andrew_embley_deserve_the_norm_smith_medal/ Did Andrew Embley deserve the Norm Smith Medal?] - ''[[Herald Sun]]''. Published 30 September 2006. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref>
Embley played only 13 out of a possible 24 games during the [[2007 AFL season|2007 season]], missing seven games between rounds 6 and 12 and four games at the end of the season due to a hamstring injury.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/08/13/2003956.htm Eagles' Embley troubled by hamstring injury] - ABC News. Published 13 August 2007. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref> He was dropped as Eagles vice-captain for the 2007 season.<ref>[http://www.footywire.com/club/sports/player-101-biography.html Andrew Embley player profile] - Footywire. Retrieved 28 May 2011</ref> Embley played 42 out of a possible 44 games during the [[2008 AFL season|2008]] and [[2009 AFL season|2009 seasons]] in a shift to a more midfield role. He played his 150th game for the Eagles against the {{AFL WB}} in [[2008 AFL season#Round 6|Round 6, 2008]] in a 60-point loss, earning life membership of the club. He received three Brownlow votes for a best-on-ground performance against the Western Bulldogs in [[2009 AFL season#Round 19|Round 19, 2009]], getting 32 possessions and scoring four goals.<ref name="afltables"/><ref>[http://www.contestedfooty.com/2009/08/western-bulldogs-vs-west-coast-round-19/ Western Bulldogs vs. West Coast – Round 19 match review] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009135556/http://www.contestedfooty.com/2009/08/western-bulldogs-vs-west-coast-round-19/ |date=9 October 2011 }} - Contested Footy. Published 8 August 2009. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref> Embley played 20 games in [[2010 AFL season|2010]], including his 200th game in the AFL against {{AFL Ade}} in [[2010 AFL season#Round 10|Round 10]].<ref>[http://www.perthnow.com.au/sport/no-party-for-west-coast-200-gamer-andrew-embley/story-e6frg1wu-1225888182710 No party for West Coast 200-gamer Andrew Embley]</ref> After a strong pre-season, Embley started the [[2011 West Coast Eagles season|2011 season]] with two best-on-ground efforts against {{AFL Nor}} and {{AFL Por}}, receiving some credit for West Coast's strong start to the season after a wooden spoon the previous year.<ref>[http://www.perthnow.com.au/sport/afl/west-coast-eagles-delighted-with-andrew-embleys-strong-form/story-e6frg1xu-1226032832988 West Coast Eagles delighted with Andrew Embley's strong form] - PerthNow. Published 3 April 2011. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/afl/sydney-swans-on-andrew-embley-red-alert/story-e6frexwr-1226035622454 Sydney Swans on Andrew Embley red alert] - ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]''. Published 8 April 2011. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref> The round eight [[Western Derby]] against {{AFL Fre}} was the only match Embley missed through the entire season, playing 24 out of a possible 25 games, and also recording several personal bests, including career-high numbers in disposals, tackles, and Brownlow votes.<ref name="afltables"/>
In the [[2012 NAB Cup]], Embley injured his left shoulder, but played the first two games of the [[2012 AFL season|regular season]] before opting to have surgery, missing much of the Eagles' season as a result.<ref>[http://www.watoday.com.au/afl/west-coast-eagles/eagle-embley-out-for-16-weeks-20120411-1wpob.html Eagle Embley out for 16 weeks] – WAToday. Published 11 April 2012. Retrieved 15 August 2012.</ref> He returned to football via Swan Districts, his first WAFL match since the 2002 season.<ref>Quartermaine, Braden (2012). ([http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/afl/west-coast-veteran-andrew-embley-survives-shoulder-test-in-wafl/story-e6frepf6-1226437680729 West Coast veteran Andrew Embley survives shoulder test in WAFL] –''[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]]'' online. Published 29 July 2012. Retrieved 30 September 2012.</ref> Having successful tested the durability of his shoulder, Embley returned to West Coast's side for the round 20 match against {{AFL Gee}}, starting as the substitute.<ref>[http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/afl-eagles-regain-embley-for-cats-clash-20120809-23wtv.html AFL Eagles regain Embley for Cats' clash] – ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''. Published 9 August 2012. Retrieved 15 August 2012.</ref> He played every remaining game of West Coast's season, recording 22 disposals and four goals in the club's elimination final defeat of {{AFL NM}}.<ref>Chadwick, Justin (2012). [http://www.foxsports.com.au/afl/afl-premiership/west-coast-eagles-v-north-melbourne-kangaroos-afl-elimination-final-patersons-stadium-perth/story-e6frf3e3-1226468406211 West Coast thump North Melbourne at Patersons Stadium to book semi-final against Collingwood] – Fox Sports. Published 9 September 2012. Retrieved 30 September 2012.</ref> However, in the following week's qualifying final loss to {{AFL Col}}, Embley turned the ball over late in the game, resulting in a Collingwood goal, with the ''[[Herald Sun]]'' describing him as "at one of his lowest ebbs".<ref>Quartermaine, Braden (2012). [http://www.heraldsun.com.au/afl/more-news/andrew-embley-must-live-with-his-mistake-which-cost-west-coast-a-goal/story-e6frf9jf-1226474927408 Andrew Embley must live with his mistake which cost West Coast a goal] – ''[[Herald Sun]]'' online. Published 16 September 2012. Retrieved 30 September 2012.</ref> At the end of the 2012 season, he signed a further one-year extension to his contract with West Coast.<ref>[http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/breaking/14905645/embley-heads-list-of-eagles-re-signings/ Embley heads list of Eagles re-signings] – ''[[The West Australian]]''. Published 20 September 2012. Retrieved 30 September 2012.</ref>
In what was to be his final season at AFL level, Embley was again troubled by injury, straining a hamstring in the [[2013 NAB Cup|NAB Cup]] and missing another three weeks with a foot injury early in the season.<ref>[http://www.afl.com.au/news/2013-03-03/eagle-down "Embley injury blow"] – Australian Football League. Published 3 March 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.watoday.com.au/afl/afl-news/embley-set-for-return-for-eagles-against-gws-20130521-2jyrz.html "Embley set for return for Eagles against GWS"] – WA Today. Published 21 May 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref> He also struggled for consistency during the season—of his eleven matches during the season, he played three consecutive matches only once.<ref name="afltables"/> Embley spent portions of the season in the WAFL, averaging 23 disposals over five games for Swan Districts.<ref name="waflprofile"/> When he did play for West Coast, he was often used as [[Interchange (Australian rules football)|substitute]], especially towards the end of the season.<ref>Braden Quartermaine (2013). [http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/retiring-west-coast-eagles-veteran-andrew-embley-concedes-he-has-been-struggling-to-play-out-games/story-fni5faul-1226705975901 "Retiring West Coast Eagles veteran Andrew Embley concedes he has been struggling to play out games"] – ''Herald Sun''. Published 28 August 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref> Embley announced his retirement towards the end of the 2013 season, retiring at the same time as [[Adam Selwood]], a premiership teammate.<ref>Chadwick, Justin (2013). [http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/eagle-andrew-embley-retires-from-afl-20130828-2sqc3.html "Eagle Andrew Embley retires from AFL"] – ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. Published 28 August 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref> The pair, who had not been regular selections in the team throughout the season, were selected for what was described as "farewell game" in the team's final match of the season, at home against Adelaide.<ref>Gary Stocks (2013). [http://www.westcoasteagles.com.au/news/2013-08-29/favourite-sons-named "Favourite sons named"] – West Coast Eagles. Published 29 August 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref> The match was Embley's 250th at AFL level, and he became the seventh West Coast player to reach that milestone.<ref>Gary Stocks (2013). [http://www.westcoasteagles.com.au/news/2013-08-28/a-rare-gem.workstation "A rare gem"] – West Coast Eagles. Published 28 August 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref>

==Personal life== Embley married Rayne Ella Bryant, the daughter of [[Kevin Bryant]], who played for {{WAFL EP}} and {{AFL NM}}, in December 2006. The couple have three children together: a daughter, Autumn Claire (born September 2009), and two sons, Lux Edward (born June 2011) and Van (born May 2013).<ref>[http://www.perthnow.com.au/entertainment/perth-confidential/andrew-embley-and-rayne-welcome-baby-autumn-claire/story-e6frg30u-1225772219087 Andrew Embley and Rayne welcome baby Autumn Claire] - PerthNow. Published 12 September 2009. Retrieved 28 May 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.perthnow.com.au/entertainment/perth-confidential/celebrity-baby-boom-at-st-john-of-god/story-e6frg30l-1226068619397 Celebrity baby boom at St John of God] - PerthNow. Published 3 June 2011. Retrieved 3 June 2011.</ref><ref>Michael Washbourne (2013). [http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/west-coast-eagles-veteran-andrew-embley-earns-afl-recall/story-fni5faul-1226654036099 West Coast Eagles veteran Andrew Embley earns AFL recall] – ''Herald Sun''. Published 30 May 2013. Retrieved 2 September 2013.</ref> Outside of football, Embley co-owns a seafood restaurant, ''Beluga'', in [[Claremont, Western Australia|Claremont]], with [[Dean Cox]], which opened in April 2011.<ref>Williams, Gail (2010). [http://www.perthnow.com.au/lifestyle/west-coast-veteran-embley-set-to-open-his-own-restaurant/story-e6frg3gc-1225914192799 West Coast veteran Embley set to open his own restaurant] – Perth Now. Published 4 September 2010. Retrieved 12 March 2012.</ref><ref>Williams, Gail (2011). [http://www.perthnow.com.au/lifestyle/catch-of-the-day/story-e6frg3gc-1226048506164 Catch of the day] – ''[[Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]]''. Published 2 May 2011. Retrieved 12 March 2012.</ref> He also operates a cooking demonstration business, Cooking With Embers,<ref>[http://www.cookingwithembers.com.au/ Home Page] – Cooking With Embers. Retrieved 12 March 2012.</ref> and participated in the inaugural edition of Celebrity Chef in 2011, a charity cooking event.<ref>[http://www.celebchef.com.au/andrew-embley.php Andrew Embley] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605171751/http://www.celebchef.com.au/andrew-embley.php |date=5 June 2013 }} – Celebrity Chef. Retrieved 12 March 2012.</ref>
Andrew also has a strong passion in property [[investment]]. He is currently the [[business development]] manager of [[Burswood, Western Australia|Burswood]]-based property investment [[consulting firm]] Investwise.<ref>[http://investwise.net.au/about-us/ Investwise – Meet the Team]</ref>

revision.text:
{{for|the French mathematician|Joseph Fourier}} {{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western philosophy]] |era = [[19th-century philosophy]] |image = Hw-fourier.jpg |birth_name = François Marie Charles Fourier |birth_date = {{birth date|1772|4|7|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Besançon]], France |death_date = {{death date and age|1837|10|10|1772|4|7|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Paris]], France |school_tradition = [[Utopian socialism]]
[[Fourierism]] |main_interests = [[Political philosophy]]
[[Economics]]
[[Philosophy of desire]] |notable_ideas = [[Phalanstère]]
"Attractive work" |influences = [[Nicolas-Edme Rétif]]{{cite encyclopedia| first= Jean-René |last= Suratteau| title= Restif (de la Bretonne) Nicolas Edme| editor= [[Albert Soboul]] | work= Dictionnaire historique de la Révolution française| place= Paris| publisher= PUF, 1989; Quadrige, 2005| edition= 2nd | pages= 897–898}} |influenced = [[Pierre-Joseph Proudhon]], [[Joseph Déjacque]], [[Karl Marx]], [[Peter Kropotkin]], [[Victor Prosper Considerant]], [[Walter Benjamin]], [[Émile Armand]], [[Paul Goodman (writer)|Paul Goodman]], [[André Breton]], [[Herbert Marcuse]], [[Raoul Vaneigem]], [[Bob Black]], [[Hakim Bey]], [[David Harvey]] |signature = }} {{Socialism sidebar}} '''François Marie Charles Fourier''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|f|ʊr|i|eɪ|,_|-|i|ər}};{{Dictionary.com|Fourier}} {{IPA-fr|ʃaʁl fuʁje|lang}}; 7 April 1772 – 10 October 1837) was a French [[philosopher]], influential early [[socialist]] thinker and one of the founders of [[utopian socialism]]. Some of Fourier's social and moral views, held to be radical in his lifetime, have become mainstream thinking in modern society. For instance, Fourier is credited with having originated the word "[[feminism]]" in 1837.[[#Reference-idGoldstein1982|Goldstein 1982]], p. 92. Fourier's social views and proposals inspired a whole movement of [[intentional communities]]. Among them in the United States were the community of [[Utopia, Ohio|Utopia]], [[Ohio]]; [[La Reunion (Dallas)|La Reunion]] near present-day [[Dallas]], [[Texas]]; the [[North American Phalanx]] in [[Red Bank, New Jersey|Red Bank]], [[New Jersey]]; [[Brook Farm]] in [[West Roxbury]], [[Massachusetts]]; the [[Community Place]] and [[Alasa Farms|Sodus Bay Phalanx]] in New York State; [[Silkville, Kansas]] in [[Kansas]]; and several others. Fourier later inspired a diverse array of revolutionary thinkers and writers. ==Life== Fourier was born in [[Besançon]], France on 7 April 1772.[[#Reference-idSerenyi1967|Serenyi 1967]], p. 278. The son of a small businessman, Fourier was more interested in architecture than in his father's trade. He wanted to become an engineer, but the local military engineering school accepted only sons of noblemen. Fourier later said he was grateful that he did not pursue engineering, because it would have consumed too much of his time and taken away from his true desire to help humanity.[[#Reference-idPellarin1846|Pellarin 1846]], p. 14. When his father died in 1781, Fourier received two-fifths of his father's estate, valued at more than 200,000 [[francs]].[[#Reference-idPellarin1846|Pellarin 1846]], p. 7. This inheritance enabled Fourier to travel throughout Europe at his leisure. In 1791 he moved from [[Besançon]] to [[Lyon]], where he was employed by the merchant M. Bousquet.[[#Reference-idPellarin1846|Pellarin 1846]], p. 235. Fourier's travels also brought him to Paris, where he worked as the head of the [[Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques|Office of Statistics]] for a few months. From 1791 to 1816 Fourier was employed in Paris, [[Rouen]], [[Lyon]], [[Marseille]], and [[Bordeaux]].[[#Reference-idPellarin1846|Pellarin 1846]], pp. 235–236. As a traveling salesman and correspondence clerk, his research and thought was time-limited: he complained of "serving the knavery of merchants" and the stupefaction of "deceitful and degrading duties." He took up writing, and his first book was published in 1808 but it only sold few copies. Surprisingly, after six years the book fell into the hands of Monsieur Just Muiron who eventually became Fourier's patron. Fourier produced most of his writings between 1816 and 1821. In 1822, he tried to sell his books again but with no success.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=NcO7t8G-yQ8C&pg=PA535&lpg=PA535&dq=Fran%C3%A7ois+Marie+Charles+Fourier's+first+book+was+published+in+1808&source=bl&ots=cyeU5UqsNO&sig=l2HxUzbNBtMhQykL8q8bycArXqE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJ-9uU5b3XAhWQF-wKHeHKAnAQ6AEIWTAJ#v=onepage&q=Fran%C3%A7ois%20Marie%20Charles%20Fourier's%20first%20book%20was%20published%20in%201808&f=false|title=Faces in the Street|last=Wilson|first=Pip|date=2006|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=9781430300212|language=en}} Fourier died in Paris in 1837.[[#Reference-idPellarin1846|Pellarin 1846]], p. 213. ==Ideas== Fourier declared that concern and [[cooperation]] were the secrets of social success. He believed that a society that cooperated would see an immense improvement in their productivity levels. Workers would be recompensed for their labors according to their contribution. Fourier saw such cooperation occurring in communities he called "phalanxes," based upon structures called [[Phalanstère]]s or "grand hotels". These buildings were four-level apartment complexes where the richest had the uppermost apartments and the poorest had a ground-floor residence. Wealth was determined by one's job; jobs were assigned based on the interests and desires of the individual. There were incentives: jobs people might not enjoy doing would receive higher pay. Fourier considered [[trade]], which he associated with Jews, to be the "source of all evil" and advocated that Jews be forced to perform farm work in the phalansteries.{{cite book| first= Richard H.| last= Roberts| title= Religion and the Transformations of Capitalism: Comparative Approaches| publisher= Routledge| year= 1995| page= 90}} By the end of his life, Fourier advocated the return of Jews to Palestine with the assistance of the [[Rothschilds]].Rubenstein, Richard L., and John K. Roth. Approaches to Auschwitz: The Legacy of the Holocaust. London: SCM, 1987, p.71 [[John K. Roth]] and [[Richard L. Rubenstein]] have seen Fourier as motivated by economic and religious antisemitism, rather than the [[racial antisemitism]] that would emerge later in the century.Rubenstein, Richard L., and John K. Roth. Approaches to Auschwitz: The Legacy of the Holocaust. London: SCM, 1987, p.71 ===Attack on civilization=== Fourier characterized poverty (not inequality) as the principal cause of disorder in society, and he proposed to eradicate it by sufficiently high wages and by a "decent minimum" for those who were not able to work.[[#Reference-idCunliffe2001|Cunliffe 2001]], p. 461. Fourier used the word civilization in a negative sense and as such "Fourier's contempt for the respectable thinkers and ideologies of his age was so intense that he always used the terms philosopher and civilization in a pejorative sense. In his lexicon civilization was a depraved order, a synonym for perfidy and constraint ... Fourier's attack on civilization had qualities not to be found in the writing of any other social critic of his time."{{cite book| first= Johnathan| last= Beecher| title= Charles Fourier: The Visionary and His World| publisher= University of California Press| year= 1986| pages= 195–196}} ===Work and liberated passions=== For [[Herbert Marcuse]] "The idea of libidinal work relations in a developed industrial society finds little support in the tradition of thought, and where such support is forthcoming it seems of a dangerous nature. The transformation of labor into pleasure is the central idea in Fourier's giant socialist utopia."{{cite book| first= Herbert| last= Marcuse| title= [[Eros and Civilization]] | publisher= Beacon Press| place= Boston| year= 1955}}{{rp|217}} {{quote box|align=right|width=30%|quote=Fourier insists that this transformation requires a complete change in the social institutions: distribution of the social product according to need, assignment of functions according to individual faculties and inclinations, constant mutation of functions, short work periods, and so on. But the possibility of "attractive labor" (''travail attrayant'') derives above all from the release of libidinal forces . Fourier assumes the existence of an ''attraction industrielle'' which makes for pleasurable co-operation. It is based on the attraction passionnée in the nature of man, which persists despite the opposition of reason, duty, prejudice. This ''attraction passionnée'' tends toward three principal objectives: the creation of "luxury, or the pleasure of the five senses"; the formation of libidinal groups (of friendship and love); and the establishment of a harmonious order, organizing these groups for work in accordance with the development of the individual "passions" (internal and external "play" of faculties).{{rp|217}}}} He believed that there were twelve common passions which resulted in 810 types of character, so the ideal phalanx would have exactly 1620 people. One day there would be six million of these, loosely ruled by a world "[[omniarch]]", or (later) a [[World Congress of Phalanxes]]. He had a concern for the sexually rejected; jilted suitors would be led away by a corps of ''fairies'' who would soon cure them of their lovesickness, and visitors could consult the card-index of ''personality types'' for suitable partners for [[casual sex]]. He also defended [[homosexuality]] as a personal preference for some people. Anarchist [[Hakim Bey]] describes Fourier's ideas as follows: "In Fourier's system of Harmony all creative activity including industry, craft, agriculture, etc. will arise from liberated passion—this is the famous theory of "attractive labor." Fourier sexualizes work itself—the life of the [[Phalanstery]] is a continual orgy of intense feeling, intellection, & activity, a society of lovers & wild enthusiasts."{{cite web| authorlink= Hakim Bey| first= Hakim| last= Bey| url= http://www.theanarchistlibrary.org/HTML/Hakim_Bey__The_Lemonade_Ocean___Modern_Times.html |title= The Lemonade Ocean & Modern Times|year= 1991| access-date= January 16, 2017}} ===Women's rights=== Fourier was also a supporter of [[women's rights]] in a time period when influences like [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]] were prevalent. Fourier believed that all important jobs should be open to women on the basis of skill and aptitude rather than closed on account of gender. He spoke of women as individuals, not as half the human couple. Fourier saw that "traditional" marriage could potentially hurt woman's rights as human beings and thus never married.[[#Reference-idDenslow1880|Denslow 1880]], p. 172. Writing before the advent of the term 'homosexuality', Fourier held that both men and women have a wide range of sexual needs and preferences which may change throughout their lives, including same-sex sexuality and ''androgénité''. He argued that all sexual expressions should be enjoyed as long as people are not abused, and that "affirming one's difference" can actually enhance social integration.{{cite book| first= Charles| last= Fourier| title= Le Nouveau Monde amoureux| year= 1967| postscript=. written 1816–18, not published widely until 1967. | place= Paris| publisher= Éditions Anthropos| pages= 389, 391, 429, 458, 459, 462, and 463}} Fourier's concern was to liberate every human individual, man, woman, and child, in two senses: education and the liberation of human passion.[[#Reference-idGoldstein1982|Goldstein 1982]], p. 98. ===Children and education=== On [[education]], Fourier felt that "civilized" parents and teachers saw children as little idlers.[http://www.historyguide.org/intellect/fourier.html Charles Fourier, 1772-1837 -- Selections from his Writings] Retrieved November 25, 2007. Fourier felt that this way of thinking was wrong. He felt that children as early as age two and three were very industrious. He listed the dominant tastes in all children to include, but not limited to: #Rummaging or inclination to handle everything, examine everything, look through everything, to constantly change occupations; #Industrial commotion, taste for noisy occupations; #Aping or imitative mania. #Industrial miniature, a taste for miniature workshops. #Progressive attraction of the weak toward the strong. Fourier was deeply disturbed by the disorder of his time and wanted to stabilize the course of events which surrounded him. Fourier saw his fellow human beings living in a world full of strife, chaos, and disorder.[[#Reference-idSerenyi1967|Serenyi 1967]], p. 279. Fourier is best remembered for his writings on a [[New world order (politics)|new world order]] based on unity of action and harmonious collaboration. He is also known for certain Utopian pronouncements, such as that the seas would lose their [[salinity]] and turn to [[lemonade]], and a coincidental view of [[climate change]], that the [[North Pole]] would be milder than the Mediterranean in a future phase of Perfect Harmony. {{Failed verification|date=May 2016}} [[File:Phalanstère.jpg|thumb|300px|alt=|Perspective view of Fourier's Phalanstère]] ==Influence== {{Libertarian socialism|People }} The influence of Fourier's ideas in French politics was carried forward into the [[Revolutions of 1848 in France|1848 Revolution]] and the [[Paris Commune]] by followers such as [[Victor Considerant]]. *Numerous references to Fourierism appear in [[Dostoevsky]]'s [[political fiction|political novel]] ''[[The Possessed (novel)|Demons]]'' first published in 1872{{cite web|last1=Postoutenko|first1=Kirill|title=The Influence of Anxiety: Figures of Absolute Evil in French Socialists and Dostoevsky| website= academia.edu| url= https://www.academia.edu/9262238/The_influence_of_Anxiety_Figures_of_Absolute_Evil_in_French_Socialists_and_Dostoevsky| year= 2009| accessdate=22 August 2016}} *Fourier's ideas also took root in America, with his followers starting phalanxes throughout the country, including one of the most famous, [[Utopia, Ohio]]. *[[Kent Bromley]], in his preface to [[Peter Kropotkin]]'s book ''[[The Conquest of Bread]]'', considered Fourier to be the founder of the [[Libertarian socialism|libertarian]] branch of [[Socialism|socialist]] thought, as opposed to the authoritarian socialist ideas of [[François-Noël Babeuf|Babeuf]] and [[Philippe Buonarroti|Buonarroti]].{{cite book| first= Peter| last= Kropotkin| title= The Conquest of Bread| place= New York and London| publisher= Putnam| year= 1906}} *In the mid-20th century, Fourier's influence began to rise again among writers reappraising socialist ideas outside the [[Marxism|Marxist]] mainstream. After the [[Surrealism|Surrealists]] had broken with the [[French Communist Party]], [[André Breton]] returned to Fourier, writing ''Ode à Charles Fourier'' in 1947. *[[Walter Benjamin]] considered Fourier crucial enough to devote an entire "[[konvolut]]" of his massive, projected book on the Paris arcades, the ''[[Arcades Project|Passagenwerk]]'', to Fourier's thought and influence. He writes: "To have instituted play as the canon of a labor no longer rooted in exploitation is one of the great merits of Fourier", and notes that "Only in the summery middle of the nineteenth century, only under its sun, can one conceive of Fourier's fantasy materialized." *[[Herbert Marcuse]] in his influential work ''[[Eros and Civilization]]'' praised Fourier saying that "Fourier comes closer than any other utopian socialist to elucidating the dependence of freedom on non-repressive [[Sublimation (psychology)|sublimation]]."{{rp|218}} *In 1969, [[Raoul Vaneigem]] quoted and adapted Fourier's ''Avis aux civilisés relativement à la prochaine métamorphose sociale'' in his text ''Avis aux civilisés relativement à l'autogestion généralisée''.{{cite web| first= Charles| last= Fourier| url= http://www.bopsecrets.org/SI/12.selfman.htm |title= Notice to the Civilized Concerning Generalized Self-Management}} [[File:Phalanxary colt nj.jpg|thumb|200px|[[North American Phalanx]] building in New Jersey]] *Fourier's work has significantly influenced the writings of [[Gustav Wyneken]], [[Guy Davenport]] (in his work of fiction ''[[Apples and Pears (book)|Apples and Pears]]''), [[Peter Lamborn Wilson]], and [[Paul Goodman (writer)|Paul Goodman]]. *In [[Whit Stillman]]'s film ''[[Metropolitan (1990 film)|Metropolitan]]'', the idealistic Tom Townsend describes himself as a Fourierist, and debates the success of social experiment [[Brook Farm]] with another of the characters. Bidding him goodnight, Sally Fowler says, "Good luck with your furrierism." {{sic}} *[[David Harvey (geographer)|David Harvey]], in the appendix to his book ''Spaces of Hope'', offers a personal utopian vision of the future in cities citing Fourier's ideas. *[[Libertarian socialist]] and environmentalist thinker [[Murray Bookchin]] wrote that "The Greek ideal of the rounded citizen in a rounded environment — one that reappeared in Charles Fourier’s utopian works — was long cherished by the anarchists and socialists of the last century...The opportunity of the individual to devote his or her productive activity to many different tasks over an attenuated work week (or in Fourier’s ideal society, over a given day) was seen as a vital factor in overcoming the division between manual and intellectual activity, in transcending status differences that this major division of work created, and in enhancing the wealth of experiences that came with a free movement from industry through crafts to food cultivation."{{cite web| url= http://theanarchistlibrary.org/library/murray-bookchin-the-meaning-of-confederalism| authorlink= Murray Bookchin| first= Murray | last= Bookchin| title= The Meaning of Confederalism| year= 1990}} *[[Nathaniel Hawthorne]] in Chapter 7 of his novel ''[[The Blithedale Romance]]'' gently mocks Fourier saying, {{quote|"When, as a consequence of human improvement", said I, "the globe shall arrive at its final perfection, the great ocean is to be converted into a particular kind of lemonade, such as was fashionable at Paris in Fourier's time. He calls it limonade a cedre. It is positively a fact! Just imagine the city docks filled, every day, with a flood tide of this delectable beverage!" [[#Reference-idHawthorne1852|Hawthorne]], p. 166.}} *Writers of the [[post-left anarchy]] tendency have praised the writings of Fourier. [[Bob Black]] in his work ''[[The Abolition of Work]]'' advocates Fourier's idea of attractive work as a solution to his criticisms of work conditions in contemporary society.{{cite web| quote= The secret of turning work into play, as Charles Fourier demonstrated, is to arrange useful activities to take advantage of whatever it is that various people at various times in fact enjoy doing. To make it possible for some people to do the things they could enjoy it will be enough just to eradicate the irrationalities and distortions which afflict these activities when they are reduced to work.| authorlink= Bob Black| first= Bob |last= Black| url= http://www.theanarchistlibrary.org/HTML/Bob_Black__The_Abolition_of_Work.html |title= The Abolition of Work| year= 1985| access-date= }} [[Hakim Bey]] manifested that Fourier "lived at the same time as De [[Marquis de Sade|Sade]] & [[William Blake|(William) Blake]], & deserves to be remembered as their equal or even superior. Those other two apostles of freedom & desire had no political disciples, but in the middle of the 19th century literally hundreds of communes (phalansteries) were founded on fourierist principles". ===Fourier's works=== *Fourier, Charles. ''Théorie des quatre mouvements et des destinées générales'' .(Theory of the four movements and the general destinies), appeared anonymously in Lyon in 1808. *Fourier, Charles. [[Image:David Brearly.jpg|thumb|right| David Brearley]]
'''David Brearley''' (often misspelled for ''Brearly'')<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.dickinson.edu/hist-404pinsker/2010/09/15/david-brearley-quiet-and-supportive-delegate-from-new-jersey/|title=David Brearley: Quiet and Supportive Delegate from New Jersey {{!}} History 404: US Constitution Seminar|website=blogs.dickinson.edu|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref> (June 11, 1745 – August 16, 1790) was a delegate to the [[United States|U.S.]] [[Philadelphia Convention|Constitutional Convention]] and signed the [[U.S. Constitution]] on behalf of [[New Jersey]].
==American Revolution== [[File:Coat of Arms of David Brearley.svg|175px|thumb|left|Coat of Arms of David Brearley]] With the outbreak of the [[American Revolutionary War]], Brearley was at first a captain in the [[Monmouth County, New Jersey|Monmouth County]] [[militia (United States)|militia]] after having spent many years speaking out against the Parliamentary absolutism.<ref name = soldierState>{{cite book| url = http://www.history.army.mil/books/RevWar/ss/brearly.htm| title = Soldier-Statesmen of the Constitution | id =CMH Pub 71-25| chapter = David Brearly| location = Washington D.C.| publisher = United States Army Center of Military History| first1 =Robert K.| last1 = Wright, Jr.|first2= Morris J.| last2 = MacGregor Jr.}}</ref> He eventually rose to the rank of colonel in Nathaniel Heard's New Jersey militia brigade. From 1776 to 1779 he served in the [[New Jersey Line]] of the [[Continental Army]], seeing action at [[Battle of Brandywine|Brandywine]], [[Battle of Germantown|Germantown]], and [[Battle of Monmouth|Monmouth]].
==Government service== Brearley resigned from the army in 1779 to serve as the [[New Jersey Supreme Court]] Chief Justice, succeeding [[Robert Morris (judge)|Robert Morris]]. He decided on the famous ''Holmes v. Walton'' case where he ruled that the judiciary had the authority to declare whether laws were unconstitutional or not.<ref name=soldierState/> He held the seat until 1789.
While at the Constitutional Convention in 1787, he chaired the Committee on Postponed Parts, which played a substantial role in shaping the final document.<ref>Stewart, David. "The Summer of 1787". p. 207</ref> The committee addressed questions related to the taxes, war making, patents and copyrights, relations with Indian tribes, and Franklin's compromise to require money bills to originate in the house. The biggest issue they addressed was the presidency, and the final compromise was written by Madison with the committee's input.<ref>Stewart, David. "The Summer of 1787". p. 209</ref> They adopted the earlier plan for choosing the president by electoral college, and settled on the method of choosing the president if no candidate had an electoral college majority, which many such as Madison thought would be "nineteen times out of twenty". The committee also shorted the president's term from seven years to four years, freed him to seek reelection, and moved impeachment trials from the courts to the Senate. They also created the vice president, whose only role was to succeed the president and preside over the senate. This also transferred important powers from the Senate to the president, who was given the power (which had been given to the senate by Rutledge's committee) to make treaties and appoint ambassadors.<ref>Stewart, David. "The Summer of 1787". p. 212</ref> After signing the Constitution in 1787, he headed up the New Jersey committee that approved the Constitution. In 1789, he was a [[Presidential elector]] and on September 25, 1789, he was nominated by President [[George Washington]] to be the first federal district judge for the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]], a newly created seat. He was confirmed by the Senate on September 25, 1789, and received his commission the following day. He died in that office a few months later.<ref name=soldierState/>
==Legacy== Brearley was the first Grand Master of the New Jersey Masonic Lodge.
He is buried in the churchyard of [[St. Michael's Church, Trenton, NJ|Saint Michael's Episcopal Church]] in [[Trenton, New Jersey]], and a [[cenotaph]] was placed there in 1924.<ref>{{FAG|4725}}</ref>
David Brearley High School in [[Kenilworth, New Jersey]], was named in his honor.
Brearley Street in [[Madison, Wisconsin]] is named in his honor.<ref>http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/odd/archives/002071.asp</ref>
Brearley Crescent in [[Waldwick, NJ]] is named in his honor.<ref>[[Waldwick, New Jersey]]</ref>
Brearley Lodge No.2 Masonic Lodge in Bridgeton,NJ is also named in his honor
