Morehouse]] }} {{s-end}} {{Governors of Missouri|state=expanded}} {{Subject bar|portal1=American Civil War|portal2=Biography|portal3=Missouri|portal4=Politics|commons=y|d=y|d-search=Q373590}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marmaduke, John S.}} [[Category:1833 births]] [[Category:1887 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American Civil War prisoners of war]] [[Category:Burials in Missouri]] [[Category:Cavalry commanders]] [[Category:Confederate States Army major generals]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Democratic Party state governors of the United States]] [[Category:Duellists]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in Missouri]] [[Category:Governors of Missouri]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Missouri Democrats]] [[Category:Missouri State Guard]] [[Category:People from Saline County, Missouri]] [[Category:People of Missouri in the American Civil War]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]]

{{Infobox person | name = June Fairchild | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = June Edna Wilson | birth_date = {{birth date|1946|9|3}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan Beach, California]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2015|2|17|1946|9|3}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | nationality = American | death_cause = liver cancer | occupation = Actress | alma_mater = | yearsactive = 1966-1978 | parents = | known_for = }} '''June Edna Fairchild''' (September 3, 1946 – February 17, 2015) was an [[United States|American]] actress and dancer. Fairchild starred or co-starred in more than a dozen major notable film roles before her addictions to drugs and alcohol effectively ended her professional acting career.
==Life== Fairchild was born '''June Edna Wilson''' on September 3, 1946,<ref name=latimes/> in [[Manhattan Beach, California]].<ref name=ciobit>{{cite journal|last1=Lentz III|first1=Harris|title=Obituaries|journal=Classic Images|date=April 2015|issue=478|pages=50–56}}</ref> Her father was a musician who specialized in writing gospel songs and music.<ref name=latimes/> Fairchild was raised in Manhattan Beach and graduated from [[Aviation High School (California)|Aviation High School]] in [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo Beach]].<ref name=latimes/> She was hired as a member of the [[Gazzarri's|Gazzarri Dancers]] on the 1960s syndicated [[variety show]], ''[[Hollywood A Go-Go]]'', after graduating from high school.<ref name=latimes/>
===Year of success=== During the 1960s, Fairchild lived with her then-boyfriend, [[Danny Hutton]], the lead singer of [[Three Dog Night]] for several years.<ref name=latimes>{{cite news|first=Steve|last=Chawkins|title=June Fairchild dies at 68; former actress lived on skid row |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-june-fairchild-20150219-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2015-02-18 |accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref> Fairchild was credited with conceiving the band's name, Three Dog Night.<ref name=latimes/>
In the late 1960s and 1970s Fairchild had a successful acting career. She co-starred in ''[[Head (film)|Head]]'', which was a vehicle for [[The Monkees]], in 1968; ''[[Drive, He Said]]'', which was directed by [[Jack Nicholson]], in 1971; ''[[Thunderbolt and Lightfoot]]'', which starred [[Clint Eastwood]] and [[Jeff Bridges]], in 1974; and the 1978 [[Cheech & Chong]] film, ''[[Up in Smoke]]'', in which she appeared as a drug addict who snorts [[Ajax (cleaning product)|Ajax]] soap powder.<ref name=latimes/>
===Decline=== In her later life Fairchild lived on the streets of [[Skid Row, Los Angeles]] due to her addictions.<ref name=latimes/>
In 2001, a reporter for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' ran a story about Fairchild's past career in Hollywood and her present life on the streets of Los Angeles.<ref name=latimes2>{{cite news|first=Noaki|last=Schwartz|title=A Fallen Star: Addiction: Former actress, now 54 and living on the streets, dreams of a movie comeback.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/feb/21/local/me-28123 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2001-02-21 |accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref> Fairchild was selling newspapers outside a Los Angeles courthouse at the time in an attempt to earn enough money for a [[single-room occupancy]] hotel room.<ref name=latimes/> On February 21, 2001, the same day that her story was published in the ''Los Angeles Times'', police stopped her in [[Van Nuys]] for carrying an open container. A police officer recognized her picture from the newspaper and arrested her for failure to complete her [[community service]] from a past [[drunk driving]] conviction. Fairchild was sentenced to 90 days in prison.<ref name=latimes/> In 2002, Fairchild told the ''Los Angeles Times'' that her prison sentence had triggered a pledge of sobriety.<ref name=latimes/> Friends told reporters that Fairchild remained sober until her death in 2015.<ref name=latimes/>
Fairchild spent the later years of her life living in single-room hotels in [[downtown Los Angeles]] using her [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] disability payments.<ref name=latimes/>
==Death== Fairchild died from liver cancer at a convalescent home in Los Angeles on February 17, 2015, at the age of 68.<ref name=latimes/> She was survived by her daughter, Megan Mull; a 2-month-old grandson; and her brother, Jerry Wilson. Fairchild had divorced twice.<ref name=latimes/>
==Partial filmography== *''[[Where Angels Go, Trouble Follows]]'' (1968) - June<ref>{{cite news|title=June's Easter Greeting (caption)|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2262129/where_angels_go/|agency=Independent Press-Telegram|date=April 14, 1968|page=36|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = April 21, 2015}} {{Open access}}</ref> *''[[Head (film)|Head]]'' (1968) - The Jumper *''[[Pretty Maids All in a Row]]'' (1971) - Sonny *''[[Drive, He Said]]'' (1971) - Sylvie<ref name=latimes/> *''[[Summertree]]'' (1971) - Girl in Dorm *''[[Top of the Heap (film)|Top of the Heap]]'' (1972) - Balloon Thrower *''[[Your Three Minutes Are Up]]'' (1973) - Sandi *''[[Detroit 9000]]'' (1973) - Barbara (uncredited) *''[[Thunderbolt and Lightfoot]]'' (1974) - Gloria<ref name=latimes/> *''[[Dirty O'Neil]]'' (1974) - Hitchhiker *''The Student Body'' (1976) - Mitzi *''[[Sextette]]'' (1978) - Woman Reporter *''[[Up in Smoke]]'' (1978) - Ajax Lady<ref name=latimes/> (final film role)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0265517|name=June Fairchild}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fairchild, June}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:Homeless people]] [[Category:Actors from Manhattan Beach, California]] [[Category:Deaths from liver cancer]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Kim Man-il | birth_name = Alexander Irsenovich Kim | birth_date = c. 1944 | birth_place = [[Vyatskoye, Khabarovsk Krai|Vyatskoye]], [[Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = 1947–1948 (aged 3–4) | death_place = [[Pyongyang]], [[Provisional People's Committee for North Korea|Soviet Korea]] (North Korean sources)
Vyatskoye, Russian SFSR, Soviet Union (Soviet records) | death_cause = Drowning | parents = [[Kim Il-sung]]
[[Kim Jong-suk]] }} '''Kim Man-il''' ({{korean|hangul=김만일|hanja=金萬一}}; 1944–1947/8) was the second son and child of [[North Korea]]n leader [[Kim Il-sung]] and his first wife, [[Kim Jong-suk]]. ==Biography== Soviet records show that he was born '''Alexander Irsenovich Kim''' ({{lang-ru|Александр Ирсенович Ким}}) in 1944 in the [[Russia]]n village of [[Vyatskoye, Khabarovsk Krai|Vyatskoye]]. Inside his family, he was nicknamed ''Shura''. Official North Korean biographies state that Shura and his older brother [[Kim Jong-il]] got along very well and played together.Both Jerrold Post in {{Cite journal|author=Post, Jerrold M. |year=2008 |title=Kim Jong-Il of North Korea: In the shadow of his father |journal=International Journal of Applied Psychoanalytic Studies |volume=5|issue=3|pages=191–210}} and Robert Davison who publishes ''The Inquisitor'' cite North Korean defector Yi Ki-bong (이기봉, 李基奉) for statements that shed some doubt on this. Davison quotes from Yi's book, ''What Kind of Man is Kim Jong II [sic: Kim, Chŏng-il]'' (most likely Yi's chapter in ''민족사 입장 에서 본 김 일성 정권''): “Kim was very mischievous when a child. When he saw an insect, he trampled on it. After Korea’s liberation from Japanese occupation, the Kim II-sung family lived in a house in Mansu-tong, Central District, P’yongyang. In the early summer of 1948, his younger brother, Shura (then three years old) drowned. Kim Jong II was there at the time. I learned later how the accident occurred. The two brothers were playing in the pond right by the edge. Kim Jong II raised his face faster than his brother, and pushed his brother’s face back into water. He did that over and over.” {{Cite web|author=Davison, Robert|title=Despot of the Week #5 – Kim Jong II |date=26 August 2009 |url=https://robertod.wordpress.com/2009/08/26/despot-of-the-week-5-kim-jong-ii/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830223323/http://robertod.wordpress.com/2009/08/26/despot-of-the-week-5-kim-jong-ii/ |archivedate=30 August 2009 |deadurl=no}} Kim Man-il's death is shrouded in mystery. North Korean sources claim that in the summer of 1947 or 1948, Shura and his brother were playing in a pond in the city of [[Pyongyang]], when Shura accidentally drowned.None of the sources appear to be entirely authoritative, and many show a bias towards or opposed to the Kim regime. {{Cite web|title=Kim Family |publisher=North Korea Leadership Watch |url=https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/kim-family/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717111813/https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/kim-family/ |archivedate=17 July 2015 |deadurl=no}} gives a date of July 1947. Sources such as {{Cite book|author=Behnke, Alison |year=2008 |title=Kim Jong Il's North Korea |edition=first |location=Minneapolis, Minnesota |publisher=Twenty-First Century Books |page=45 |isbn=978-0-8225-7282-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1FaXAgAAQBAJ}} give a generic 1947. While sources like {{Cite book|year=2002|title=North Korea: General Secretary Kim Jong-il Handbook |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=International Business Publications|page=38 |isbn=978-0-7397-6344-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=baRrfmjDnbYC}} give a generic 1948. However, Russian sources indicate that he fell in a well in Vyatskoye and drowned, prior to the family moving back to Korea.{{Cite news|author=Chung Byoung-sun|date=22 August 2002|title=Sergeyevna Remembers Kim Jong Il|newspaper=Chosunilbo|url=http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200208/200208220040.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021124073259/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200208/200208220040.html|archivedate=24 November 2002|deadurl=yes}} Official records state that Kim Jong-il was devastated and could never get over the trauma of losing his younger brother. Kim Man-il's alleged grave is located in Vyatskoye.https://web.archive.org/web/20021124073259/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200208/200208220040.html In 1949, his mother, [[Kim Jong-suk]] died while giving birth to a stillborn girl. {{Kim Il-sung family}} ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} {{Clear}} {{Family of Kim Jong-il}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kim, Man-il}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:1940s deaths]] [[Category:People from Khabarovsky District]] [[Category:North Korean people]] [[Category:Koryo-saram]] [[Category:Year of death uncertain]] [[Category:Kim dynasty (North Korea)]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:Children of national leaders]] [[Category:20th-century North Korean people]]

revision.text:
[[File:Laverna Katie Dollimore.png|thumbnail|Laverna Katie Dollimore]] '''Laverna "Verna" Katie Dollimore''' (January 22, 1922 – October 24, 2011) was one of six Canadians awarded the [[Order of Canada]] for her participation in the [[Canadian Caper]], in which the Canadian government and the [[CIA]] orchestrated the cover rescue of six American diplomats in Iran (1979). Her Order of Canada Medal is on display at the [[Maritime Command Museum]].
Laverna Katie Dollimore was born in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] on 22 January 1922. Her parents, William Dollimore and Eva Somner, emigrated to Canada in 1915 on the penultimate voyage of the [[RMS Lusitania]]. Dollimore was the youngest of three children, preceded by brother, Hedley, and sister, Neysa. She attended Oakwood Collegiate High School and then Western Technical Commercial School for business, graduating in 1938.<ref name="ryell">{{cite news|last1=Ryell|first1=Nora|title=Dollimore got more adventure than she bargained for in Iran|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/dollimore-got-more-adventure-than-she-bargained-for-in-iran/article4180935/|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=The Globe and Mail|date=13 December 2011|ref=1}}</ref><ref name="wright">{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Robert|title=Our woman in Tehran|url=https://static1.squarespace.com/static/55f9740de4b06788affc824b/t/55fffeb0e4b0b10a56e526d3/1442840240198/Dollimore.pdf|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=The Ottawa Citizen|date=5 November 2011|ref=2|page=B4}}</ref>
For five years she did secretarial or bookkeeping jobs for companies in Toronto including, Jenny Lind Candy Shops and Dominion Paper Box Co.<ref name="obit">{{cite news|title=Laverna Dollimore - Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/ottawacitizen/obituary.aspx?pid=154307356|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=The Ottawa Citizen|date=29 October 2011|ref=3}}</ref> In 1942 she joined the [[Women’s Royal Canadian Naval Service]] and was posted to [[HMCS Cornwallis]] in Halifax. Despite taking the Petty Officer exam, the war concluded before Dollimore could follow that path and she returned to Toronto to continue in her previous line of work.<ref name="ryell" />
In 1956, she took the public service exam and joined the Department of External Affairs. Dollimore worked in a number of Canadian embassies, such as Cairo,<ref>{{cite news|title=L.K. Dollimore Goes to Cairo|work=The Globe and Mail|date=22 April 1957|location=Toronto|page=15}} {{subscription required |via= [[ProQuest]]}}</ref> following the Suez Crisis, Poland, Kuala Lumpur, Leopoldville (now [[Kinshasa]], DRC), and many others. During her time she worked for notable members of the diplomatic corps, including: [[Robert Ford (poet)|Robert Ford]], [[G. Hamilton Southam]], [[Charles Ritchie (diplomat)|Charles Ritchie]], [[Paul Martin Sr]].<ref name="ryell" /><ref name="wright" />
She joined the [[International Commission for Supervision and Control]], under [[Percy Stewart Cooper]] in Laos in 1969. For her services there she received the [[Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal]].<ref name="ryell" />
Dollimore’s most notable posting came in 1977, when she joined the Canadian embassy in Tehran, just ahead of the [[Iranian Revolution]]. There, she was the personal secretary to [[Kenneth D. Taylor|Kenneth Taylor]] and assisted in the ‘Canadian Caper’. Despite being given the option to leave Tehran in 1979, Dollimore remained until 1980 and, along with Roger Lucy, Ken Taylor, Sgt. Claude Gauthier, was one of the last Canadian’s to leave the embassy in Tehran.(2). For her service, she received the Order of Canada.<ref name="ryell" /><ref name="wright" /><ref name="aided">{{cite news|title=Aided escape, 8 Canadians to be honored|work=The Globe and Mail|date=1 July 1980|ref=5|location=Toronto|page=3}} {{subscription required |via= [[ProQuest]]}}</ref>
For the remainder of her time with Foreign Affairs, Dollimore was posted to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.<ref name="ryell" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=King|first1=Pauline|title=A surprise birthday party for Maureen Forrester|work=The Globe and Mail|date=31 July 1980|ref=6|location=Toronto|page=T5}} {{subscription required |via= [[ProQuest]]}}</ref> She retired in 1983 to Brighton Ont. Every five years she attended a ‘Canadian Caper’ reunion, hosting the 2005 party.<ref name="ryell" /><ref name="wright" /> She died of natural causes in 2011.<ref name="obit" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/peelheritage/with/6323299621/ Photographs of Laverna Dollimore]. McCloud Collection, [[Peel Art Gallery, Museum and Archives]], on [[Flickr]]. Retrieved 18 November 2016.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dollimore, Laverna Katie}} [[Category:Members of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:People from Toronto]] [[Category:Secretaries]]

{{notability|biographies|date=February 2015}}
'''Lisa Charleyboy''' is a First Nations ([[Tsilhqot’in]]) writer and social entrepreneur. She is the editor-in-chief of ''Urban Native Magazine'', which focuses on pop culture with an Indigenous twist. She writes, and also does appearances on radio shows and T.V. interviews to promote her magazine and give her opinion on current Aboriginal issues in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mediaindigena.com/lisa-charleyboy|title = Lisa Charleyboy|date = December 12, 2014|accessdate = |website = Media Indegina|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Charleyboy has said in interviews that she considers herself a [[feminist]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.roommagazine.com/blog/exclusive-interview-preview-lisa-charleyboy|title = Exclusive Interview Preview with Lisa Charleyboy|date = |accessdate = December 15, 2014|website = Room|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and portrays a positive representation of Aboriginal people in her magazine.
Charleyboy has written about [[cultural appropriation]], pop culture, and politics, and has been named one of Toronto’s Top Bloggers and one of Canada’s Top Ten Fashion Bloggers. In 2013, she was named by ''[[Huffington Post]]'' as one of three Aboriginal millennials to watch,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/05/10/millenials-first-nations-generation-y_n_3231763.html|title=Millennial First Nations: 3 Young Aboriginal Canadians To Watch|date=2013-05-10|work=HuffPost Canada|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-CA}}</ref> and recommended for a Toronto DiverseCity Fellowship for 2013-2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.annickpress.com/author/Lisa-Charleyboy|title = Lisa Charleyboy|date = n.d.|accessdate = December 15, 2014|website = Annick Press|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Charleyboy moved from [[Abbotsford, British Columbia]] to Toronto to attend [[Ryerson University]] for Fashion Communication. Her love of magazines, united with her desire to become a fashion editor, led her to transfer to [[York University]] for Professional Writing.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.lisacharleyboy.com/|title = Lisa Charleyboy|date = December 14, 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Career == In 2007 Charleyboy created a blog, [http://urbannativegirl.tv/ Urban Native Girl], (UNG) which is all about pop-culture with an Indigenous twist.<ref name="SheDoes">{{Cite web|url = http://www.shedoesthecity.com/lisa-charleyboy-founder-of-urban-native-magazine|title = Lisa Charleyboy, Founder of Urban Native Magazine|date = November 6, 2013|accessdate = December 15, 2014|website = She Does the City|publisher = |last = Cullingham|first = Haley}}</ref>
In 2013 Urban Native Magazine was created as a spin-off of Charleyboy's blog, which is a Native lifestyle magazine geared toward inspiring Indigenous youth with positive success stories.<ref name="SheDoes" /> Urban Native Magazine is aimed towards Aboriginal Canadians aged from 15-35. Many different types of social media are used to create positive change about Aboriginals and breaking the stereotypes and generalizations down.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://business.financialpost.com/2013/11/03/an-aboriginal-storyteller-for-the-digital-generation-entrepreneur-aims-to-get-native-culture-in-front-of-todays-youth/|title = An Aboriginal Storyteller for the digital generation:Entrepreneur aims to get native culture in front of today's youth|date = November 3, 2013|accessdate = December 15, 2014|website = Financial Post|publisher = |last = Bitti|first = Mary}}</ref>
In 2014 Charleyboy released a book with author Mary Beth Leatherdadale called "Dreaming in Indian: Contemporary Native American Voices".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.annickpress.com/Dreaming-in-Indian|title = Dreaming in Indian Contemporary Native American Voices|date = 2014|accessdate = December 2014|website = Dreaming in Indian|publisher = Annick Press|last = |first = }}</ref>
Charleyboy has also served as a board member for Association for the Native Development of Visual and Performing Arts (ANDVPA), the Young Indigenous Professionals, and is now the Director of Communications for the Aboriginal Professionals of Canada (APAC). She has also been invited to give talks at Harvard University and to Aboriginal Women Entrepreneurs, and has become a regular writer/contributor and guest in the media.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/shannon-skinner/urban-native-girl-blogger_b_4013135.html|title = Lisa Charleyboy's Mission to Empower Aboriginal Canadians|date = September 29, 2014|accessdate = December 13, 2014|website = Huffington Post|publisher = |last = Skinner|first = Shannon}}</ref>
In 2015, she hosted the summer documentary and interview series ''New Fire'' for [[CBC Radio One]].
== Publications == === Indigenous === *"Not Your Pocahontas: Breaking the Stereotypes of a 21st Century Urban Native", to be released in August 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chapters.indigo.ca/en-ca/books/not-your-pocahontas-breaking-the/9781633534230-item.html|title=Not Your Pocahontas: Breaking The Stereotypes Of A 21st Century Urban Native, Book by Lisa Charleyboy (Paperback) {{!}} chapters.indigo.ca|last=Inc.|first=Indigo Books & Music,|website=www.chapters.indigo.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref> *"#NotYourPrincess: Voices of Native American Women." September 12, 2017 *"Urban Tribes: Native Americans in the City, September 9, 2015 *"Dreaming in Indian: Contemporary Native American Voices", 2014 *"[[Idle No More]]: Canada’s Indigenous People Are Demanding a Better Deal," [[The Guardian]], January 2013 *"No Doubt, Exploiting ‘hot’ Native American Stereotypes is never OK", The Guardian, November 2012 *"In the Arctic, A Hunger for Ancestral Foods", Spirituality & Health, November 2012 *"The Ancient Art of Smudging", Spirituality & Health, November 2012 *"Native Fashion; The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly", CBC, January 2012 *"2010 Winter Olympics token tribute and Memorial March for Indigenous Women" Georgia Straight, February 14, 2010
=== Fashion === *"Urban Native Girl: Huntress On The Rise", Indian Country Magazine, August 2011 *"Urban Native Girl Muks It Up", Indian Country Magazine, February 2011 *"Fall in love with the season’s top trends", MSN.ca, September 2010 *"Luggage That’s Worth Its (light) weight", Travel Goods, Fashion and Accessories, Summer 2010 *"‘Bags that Really Have It All", Travel Goods, Fashion and Accessories, Summer 2010 *"Spring Fashion Trends", MSN.ca, February 2010
=== Lifestyle === *"Go Green with your Beauty Routine", MSN.ca, March 2010 *"Destress Your Life", MSN.ca, January 2010 *"Original Wedding Gifts", MSN.ca, February 2010
=== Education and Employment === *"Behind Inclusion Works, Canada’s top Aboriginal Career Convention", Job Postings Magazine, October 2012 *"Canadian Roots Exchange Brings Aboriginal Education to Life", Job Postings Magazine, October 2012 *"Northward Bound", Job Postings Magazine, November 2010 *"Aboriginal Opportunities", Job Postings Magazine, September 2010
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Marina Barampama | image = | image_size = | smallimage = | alt = | caption = | order = | office = [[Vice President of Burundi]] | term_start = 8 September 2006 | term_end = 8 February 2007 | president = [[Pierre Nkurunziza]] | predecessor = [[Alice Nzomukunda]] | successor = | prior_term = | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1969}} | birth_place = | citizenship = | nationality = [[Burundi]] | party = [[National Council for the Defense of Democracy – Forces for the Defense of Democracy|CNDD–FDD]] (former)
[[Union for Peace and Development|UPD]] (current) }} '''Marina Barampama''' (born 1969) is a [[Burundi]]an politician. She was elected Second [[Vice President of Burundi|Vice President]] on 8 September 2006, replacing [[Alice Nzomukunda]]. She remained in post for six months, until she was sacked for her support of [[Hussein Radjabu]]. Formerly a member of the [[National Council for the Defense of Democracy-Forces for the Defense of Democracy]] (CNDD–FDD), she is now General Secretary of the [[Union for Peace and Development]]. ==Political career== After the resignation of Vice President [[Alice Nzomukunda]] over corruption and human rights abuses, Barampama was nominated for the role by [[President of Burundi|President]] [[Pierre Nkurunziza]] on 8 September 2006. She was almost unknown, and the members of the opposition party, [[Union for National Progress]] (UPRONA), walked out of the vote in protest over the lack of information provided about her. They subsequently argued that Barampama's election was invalid, since without their members, there were not enough members voting to form a [[quorum]].{{cite news|title='Unknown' elected as Burundi VP|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/5326846.stm|accessdate=27 October 2016|work=[[BBC News]]|date=8 September 2006}} She was sacked by Nkurunziza on 8 February 2007; he attributed this to insubordination and irresponsibility. Barampama had been a supporter of [[Hussein Radjabu]], the former chairman of the [[National Council for the Defense of Democracy – Forces for the Defense of Democracy]] (CNDD–FDD), who was ousted as chairman by the President shortly before Barampama's sacking.{{cite news|title=Burundi's president sacks deputy|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/6345751.stm|accessdate=27 October 2016|work=[[BBC News]]|date=9 February 2007}} Radjabu was subsequently arrested and imprisoned for 13 years for subversion.{{cite news|title=Burundi jail term for 'plotter'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7330298.stm|accessdate=27 October 2016|work=BBC News|date=4 April 2008}} She subsequently switched allegiance to the [[Union for Peace and Development]] (UPD), and by 2015 had become General Secretary of the party. Following the increase in violence seen in the [[Burundian unrest (2015–present)|Burundian unrest]], and the murder of party spokesperson [[Patrice Gahungu]], Barampama feared for her life as she said that the UPN was seen as a threat to the government.{{cite news|title=Burundi: le porte-parole d’un parti d’opposition tué à Bujumbura|newspaper=RFI Afrique|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20150908-burundi-porte-parole-parti-opposition-tue-bujumbura-upd-patrice-gahungu-zedi-feruzi|accessdate=27 October 2016|date=8 September 2015|language=French}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[Vice-President of Burundi]]|before=[[Alice Nzomukunda]]|after=[[Gabriel Ntisezerana]]|years=2006–2007}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barampama, Marina}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hutu people]] [[Category:Vice-Presidents of Burundi]] [[Category:Women government ministers of Burundi]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Women vice presidents]] [[Category:National Council for the Defense of Democracy – Forces for the Defense of Democracy politicians]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox family | colour = powderblue | name = Mathews | crest =Mathews of Virginia and West Virginia arms.png | caption = Arms of the Mathews of Virginia and West Virginia <ref name=Cole>Cole, J. R. (1917). ''History of Greenbrier County.'' Greenbrier Historical Society: Lewisburg, WV. p 67–72 http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/WV-FOOTSTEPS/1999-09/0937846706 Retrieved November 2, 2012</ref> | ethnicity = [[British-American]] | birth_place = | region = [[United States]] | early_forms = [[David Mathew, knight|Mathew, Mathes]] | origin = | members = [[George Mathews (Georgia)|George Mathews]], [[Sampson Mathews]], [[Henry M. Mathews]] | otherfamilies = [[Peter Early|Early]], [[James Hervey Otey|Otey]], [[Mason M. Patrick|Patrick]], [[Thomas Posey|Posey]], [[Alexander W. Reynolds|Reynolds]] | distinctions = | traditions = | heirlooms = | estate = | meaning = | footnotes = }} The '''Mathews family''' was a [[List of United States political families|United States political family]] from [[Virginia]] and the [[American South]].<ref name=Cole/><ref name =Leonard/> Its role in public service spanned [[British colonization of the Americas|British Colonial]], [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]], and [[United States]] authority, during which seven of its members served in the [[Virginia Legislature]], while additional members in [[West Virginia]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi Territory|Mississippi]], [[Florida]] served in positions including [[Governor]], [[US Representative]], [[Consulate|US Consul]], [[State supreme court|State Supreme Court Chief Justice]], [[United States Army Air Corps|Chief of the Army Air Corps]], [[State Attorney General]], and [[State legislature (United States)|State Legislator]].<ref name =Leonard>Leonard, Cynthia Miller 1978. ''The General Assembly of Virginia, July 30, 1619-January 11, 1978: a bicentennial register of members.'' Virginia State Library., pp 105, 109.</ref>
==History== {{See also|Radyr #Mathew family}} The Mathews [[Surname etymology|surname]] originated in [[Llandaf]]f, [[Wales|Glamorgan, Wales]] with [[Sir David Mathew|Sir David Ap Mathew]] (1400-1484), a Welsh Knight and [[Llandaff|Lord of Llandaff]], who was named [[Standard Bearer of England]] after the War of the Roses [[Battle of Towton]] in 1461, where he saved the life of [[Edward IV of England|King Edward IV]].<ref>Lecture given by Mr J. Barry Davies at the Friends of Llandaff Cathedral 2003 annual lecture, published in "Friends of Llandaff Cathedral 71st annual report 2003/4"; Notes from site of Barry L. Matthews, www.users.qwest.net</ref><ref name=limbus>Clark, George T (1886), ''Limbus Patrum Morganiae et Glamorganiae'', London</ref>
[[Anthologist]] John Boots suggests that [[John Mathews (Augusta County)|John Mathews]] (d. 1757), an early settler of [[Shenandoah, Virginia]] region, was a descendant of Sir David through his 3rd great-grandson Theobald Mathew (d. 1699), who lived in [[Thurles]] in [[County Tipperary]], [[Ireland]].<ref name="Boots">Boots, John R. (1970). ''The Mat(t)hews family: an anthology of Mathews lineages''. University of Wisconsin - Madison</ref> Boots states that children of Theobald Mathew settled in [[Ulster]], [[Northern Ireland]], when the family property was passed to a [[Earl of Llandaff|senior branch]] of the family,<ref name="Rogers">Rogers, Patrick (1943). ''Father Theobald Mathew: Apostle of Temperance''. Browne and Nolan Limited, 1943, pp xi-xxi.</ref> and from Ulster immigrated to America during the early years of the [[Scotch-Irish American|Scotch-Irish]] immigration of 1717–1775.<ref>"... summer of 1717 ...", [[David Hackett Fischer|Fischer, David Hackett]], ''[[Albion's Seed: Four British Folkways in America]]'', Oxford University Press, USA (March 14, 1989), pg. 606; "... early immigration was small, ... but it began to surge in 1717.", Blethen, H.T. & Wood, C.W., ''From Ulster to Carolina'', North Carolina Division of Archives and History, 2005, pg. 22; "Between 1718 and 1775", Griffin, Patrick, ''The People with No Name'', Princeton University Press, 2001, pg 1; etc.</ref> Other historians agree that Mathews was an immigrant from Ireland, though they do not speculate on his ancestry.<ref name="Waddell">Waddell, Joseph A (1902) ''Annals of Augusta County, Virginia, from 1726 to 1871'', [http://www.roanetnhistory.org/waddellsannals.html Waddell's Annals of Augusta County, Virginia, from 1726 to 1871], retrieved October 20, 2012</ref><ref name="WashingtonLee">Washington and Lee University (1890). ''Historical Papers, Volumes 1–2''. New York Public Library: Washington and Lee University, 1890 https://books.google.com/books?id=9p4gAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA87&dq=%22sampson+mathews%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8IWVUJiMFqSa0QGKm4GQAQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22sampson%20mathews%22&f=false Retrieved November 3, 2012</ref><ref name="Herndon">Herndon, G. Melvin (1969). ''George Mathews, Frontier Patriot''. The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Vol. 77, No. 3 (Jul., 1969) pp. 307–328</ref>
===Colony of Virginia=== [[File:PyleNationmakersPre1911.jpg|thumb|right|[[Battle of Brandywine]] of the [[American Revolutionary War]]. [[George Mathews (Georgia)|George Mathews]] (1739–1812) led the [[9th Virginia Regiment]] into battle.]] [[John Mathews (Augusta County)|John Mathews]] settled in [[Augusta County, Virginia]], near [[Natural Bridge (Virginia)|Natural Bridge]], in 1742.<ref name=Orange>Orange County Virginia Deed Book 10, Dorman, pg. 54</ref> He held a variety of local offices, and served as a captain of [[Virginia militia]] in the [[French and Indian War]].<ref name=Herndon/> He and wife Ann Archer had eleven children, including George, Sampson, Archer, and William.<ref name=Cole/><ref name=Waddell/><ref name=Chalkley>Chalkley, Lyman (1912), ''Chronicles of the Scotch-Irish Settlement in Virginia, Extracted from the Original Court Records of Augusta County, 1745–1800'' (Washington, D.C.: Daughters of the American Revolution, 1912).</ref>
===Revolutionary War Era=== [[George Mathews (Georgia)|George Mathews]] (1739–1812) was a [[House of Burgesses|Virginia Burgess]] and delegate to the [[First Virginia Convention]].<ref name =Leonard/> He was a brevet [[brigadier general]] in the [[Continental Army]],<ref name= Herndon/><ref name=Patrick>Patrick, Rembert W. (2010). ''Florida Fiasco: Rampant Rebels on the Georgia-Florida Border, 1810–1815''. University of Georgia Press, 2010. {{ISBN|0-8203-3549-5}}, 9780820335490</ref> and afterward a [[Governors of Georgia|governor of Georgia]] and a [[US Representative|representative]] to the [[1st United States Congress]].<ref name= Congress>''Biographical Dictionary of the United States Congress''. Retrieved online from http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000234</ref> In 1811 he acted as a secret agent for President [[James Madison]], initiating the [[Florida Seminole Wars#Patriot War of East Florida|Patriot War of East Florida]].<ref name= Herndon/><ref name=Patrick/>
[[Sampson Mathews]] (1737–1806) was a [[Senate of Virginia|Virginia state senator]] who led the American defense against [[Benedict Arnold]]'s 1781 [[Raid of Richmond]].<ref name=Waddell/><ref name=Clem>Clem, Gladys B. (1965), ''It Happened Around Staunton in Virginia'' ([[Staunton, Virginia]]: Second Edition) p. 21–23</ref><ref name="R582_3">[[#Randall|Randall (1990)]], pp. 582–583</ref> He was a [[trustee|founding trustee]] of Liberty Hall (now [[Washington and Lee University]]).<ref name=WashingtonLee/>
Additional members of this family who served in the [[Virginia House of Delegates| Virginia legislature]] in the early years of the Republic include [[Archer Mathews]] (1744–1796), Sampson Mathews Jr., son of Sampson Mathews, and [[John Mathews (clerk)|John Mathews]] (1768-1849) and James W. Mathews, sons of William Mathews.<ref name=WashingtonLee/><ref name=Rice/><ref name="Knott p48">Knott. ''Alexander Hamilton and the Persistence of Myth'', p.48</ref><ref name=Rice>Rice, Otis K. 1986. ''A History of Greenbrier County''. Greenbrier Historical Society, p. 116</ref>
===Civil War Era=== [[File:PresidingJudgeGeorgeMathews.jpg|thumb|left|[[George Mathews (judge)|George Mathews, Jr.]] (1774–1836), Presiding Judge of the [[Louisiana Supreme Court]]]] [[George Mathews (judge)|George Mathews, Jr.]] (1774–1836), son of George Mathews, was a judge of the superior courts of the territories of [[Mississippi Territory|Mississippi]] and [[Territory of Orleans|Orleans]], and the first presiding judge of the [[Louisiana Supreme Court]] when it was established in 1813.<ref name = "Mazureau's Oration">{{cite journal| last = Dart| first = Henry P. | title = Mazureau's Oration on Mathews| journal = Louisiana Historical Quarterly| volume = 4| issue = 1| pages = 149| publisher = Louisiana Historical Society | location = New Orleans, Louisiana | date = September 22, 1922| url = https://archive.org/stream/louisianahistor02unkngoog/louisianahistor02unkngoog_djvu.txt | accessdate = 2009-05-18}}</ref> [[File:Henry M. Mathews - Brady-Handy.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.0|[[Henry M. Mathews]] (1834–1884), [[List of Governors of West Virginia|West Virginia governor]]]]
[[Mason Mathews]] (1803–1878), grandson of William Mathews, was a Virginia Delegate during the [[American Civil War]].<ref name="The American Historical Society (1923)">The American Historical Society (1923). "Mathews Family of Greenbrier." ''The History of West Virginia, Old and New'' (Chicago and New York: The American Historical Society, Inc.) 2: 7–9. http://files.usgwarchives.net/wv/greenbrier/bios/wvoldnew/m3200001.txt Retrieved 2012-10-19</ref> He was the last member of this family to be involved in Virginia politics, as Greenbrier County where he lived was taken into [[West Virginia]] on its creation in 1863.<ref name=Rice2>Rice, Otis K. 1986. A History of Greenbrier County. Greenbrier Historical Society, p. 264</ref> He and wife Eliza Reynolds had children including Henry, Alexander F., and Virginia Amanda.
[[Henry M. Mathews]] (1834–1884) was an [[List of Attorneys General of West Virginia| attorney general of West Virginia]], and [[governor of West Virginia]] during the [[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]], the first nationwide labor strike.<ref name=Addkison> Addkison-Simmons, D. (2010). Henry Mason Mathews. ''e-WV: The West Virginia Encyclopedia''. Retrieved December 11, 2012, from http://www.wvencyclopedia.org/articles/1582</ref><ref name=White1>White, J.T. (1904), ''The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography: Being the History of the United States as Illustrated in the Lives of the Founders, Builders, and Defenders of the Republic, and of the Men and Women who are Doing the Work and Moulding the Thought of the Present Time.'' New York Public Library. p 431.https://books.google.com/books?id=TnNMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA431&lpg=PA431&dq=henry+mason+mathews+biography&source=bl&ots=18B38J7BLq&sig=n-4H4rqNrtgHyakUR9jIDn0yCHM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MUWTUJvkN9Ss0AGe9oCIAw&ved=0CEcQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=henry%20mason%20mathews%20biography&f=false Retrieved November 1, 2012</ref>
[[Alexander F. Mathews]] (1838–1906) was [[aide-de-camp]] to Confederate General [[Henry A. Wise]], and later a [[West Virginia University]] [[Board of Regents|regent]].<ref name=Cole/><ref name=WVU>West Virginia University. Undergraduate catalog, Volume 1867–1869. Morgantown, WV : The University. https://archive.org/stream/undergrad6769west/undergrad6769west_djvu.txt Retrieved April 28, 2013.</ref> ===Later Generations=== [[George G. Mathews Jr.]] (1855–1944), great-grandson of George Mathews,<ref name=Boots/> was [[United States consulate|US Consul]] at [[Pará]], [[Brazil]], for President [[Grover Cleveland]],<ref name=Consular>''United States Consular Reports: Reports from the Consuls of the United States on the Commerce, Manufactures, Etc., of Their Consular Districts''. United States. Bureau of Foreign Commerce: U.S. Government Printing Office, 1807, p.28 https://books.google.com/books?id=viRJAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA28&dq=%22george+g+mathews%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=mathews&f=false Retrieved February 5, 2013</ref> and later a [[Florida House of Representatives|Florida state representative]].<ref name=Boots/>
[[William Gordon Mathews|William G. Mathews]] (1877–1923), son of Henry M. Mathews, was a [[federal judge]] and [[clerk of court]] for [[Kanawha County, West Virginia|Kanawha, West Virginia]].<ref>See David A. Skeel, Jr., ''Debt's Dominion: A History of Bankruptcy Law in America'', Princeton University Press 2001 (sample online at [http://www.pupress.princeton.edu/chapters/s7159.html]).</ref><ref name=Bar>West Virginia Bar Association (1908). The Bar: West Virginia, Volume 15. University of California. https://books.google.com/books?id=hHCmAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA6-PA12&dq=%22william+gordon+mathews%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22william%20gordon%20mathews%22&f=false Retrieved December 9, 2012</ref>
[[Mason M. Patrick]] (1863–1942), son of Virginia (Mathews) Patrick, was commander of the [[United States Army Air Service|U.S. Army Air Service]] during [[World War I]] and the [[Interwar Period]].<ref name=White>White, Robert (2001). "Mason Patrick". ''Smithsonian'', 2001</ref> He drafted and proposed the 1926 Air Corps Act to [[United States Congress|Congress]], creating the [[United States Army Air Corps|U.S. Army Air Corps]] from the existing Air Service.<ref name=White/><ref name=Head>Head, William Pace (1995). ''Every Inch a Soldier: Augustine Warner Robins and the Building of U.S. Airpower''. Volume 37 of Texas A & M University military history series. Texas A&M University Press, 1995: Issue 37, p. 75 {{ISBN|0-89096-590-0}}, 978-0-89096-590-0 https://books.google.com/books?id=5utyzXwyh1MC&pg=PA75&lpg=PA75&dq=order+of+the+british+empire+%22mason+patrick%22&source=bl&ots=6RgBAOhadj&sig=wjDtkEXYencJ2plWHiNmvnYCx7k&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_VuUUIiKIezW0gHelIGABA&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false Retrieved November 2, 2012.</ref> In 1947 the Air Corps was made into the [[United States Air Force]].<ref name=White/>
==Political Family Tree==
*John Mathews (d.1757), Augusta Parish [[vestryman]] 1746–1757; [[Justice of the Peace]] in Augusta County 1747–1757; Warden for Augusta County 1757; [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] of Augusta County militia 1742–1757. Father of Joshua Mathews, Sampson Mathews, George Mathews, Archer Mathews, and William Mathews.<ref name=Orange /><ref name=Chalkley /> **Joshua Mathews (d.1763), son of John Mathews. ***Martha Mathews (1754–1778), married [[Thomas Posey]] (1750–1818), [[US Senator]]. Daughter of Joshua Mathews <ref name=Cecere>Cecere, Michael. Captain Thomas Posey and the 7th Virginia Regiment. Westminster, MD: Heritage Books, 2005. {{ISBN|0-7884-3584-1}}.</ref> **[[Sampson Mathews]] (c. 1737–1807), Sheriff of Augusta County 1756–1764; Chancellor of Augusta County 1756–1764; Justice of the Peace in Augusta County 1764–1774; delegate to the Virginia Convention 1775; [[Virginia State Senate|Virginia State Senator]] from Augusta and surrounding counties 1776–1781, 1791-17922; a founder of [[Washington and Lee University]] 1776. [[Colonel]] in the Virginia militia 1781. Son of John Mathews.<ref name=WashingtonLee /><ref name=Chalkley /><ref name=Clem /><ref name=Foote>Foote, William H. (1855). "Sketches of Virginia: Historical and Biographical, Volume 2"'' (W.S. Martien: Harvard University). p 162. Retrieved from https://books.google.com/books?id=d6cq34x-JwcC&q=sampson+mathews#v=snippet&q=162&f=false on October 8, 2012</ref><ref name=VSL>Virginia State Library (1922), "Justices of the Peace of Colonial Virginia, 1757–1775". Davis Bottom, Superintendent Public Printing, 1922: Bulletin of the Virginia State Library https://books.google.com/books?id=wiUQAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=justices+of+the+peace+virginia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yFaYUMblHo6C8QTa7oHwCQ&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=matthews&f=false</ref> ***Sampson Mathews Jr., [[Virginia House of Delegates|Virginia Delegate]] from [[Bath County, Virginia|Bath County]] 1798–1800. Son of Sampson Mathews <ref name=WashingtonLee /> **[[George Mathews (Georgia)|George Mathews]] (1739–1812), Justice of the Peace in Augusta County 1770–1774; [[Virginia House of Burgesses|Virginia Burgess]] from Augusta County 1775; Georgia Assemblyman 1786; [[Governor of Georgia]] 1787–1788; [[US Representative]] 1789–1791; Governor of Georgia 1793–1796. [[Colonel]] in the Continental Army 1776–1783; [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] in [[United States Army]] 1811. Son of John Mathews.<ref name=Chalkley /><ref name=Patrick /><ref name=Foote /><ref name=VSL /> ***John Mathews (c.1762–1806), Georgia Supervisor of the Revenue 1794–1796. Son of George Mathews.<ref name=Patrick /> ***[[George Mathews (judge)|George Mathews Jr.]] (1774–1836), Judge of the [[Superior court]]s of the [[Territory of Mississippi]] 1804–1806; Judge of the Superior courts of the [[Territory of Orleans]] 1806–1813; Presiding Judge of the [[Louisiana Supreme Court]] 1813–1836. Son of George Mathews.<ref name=Waddell /><ref name=Patrick /> ***Charles Lewis Mathews (1776–1802), [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] in the [[United States Army]]. He married Lucy Early, sister of [[Peter Early]] (1773–1818), 28th Governor of Georgia.<ref name=Patrick /> **[[Archer Mathews]] (1744-c.1796), Virginia Delegate from [[Greenbrier County]] 1780, 1782. Son of John Mathews<ref name=Dayton>Dayton, Ruth W. (2009). "Greenbrier Pioneers and Their Homes." The History of West Virginia, Old and New (Genealogical Publishing Company, 2009) p.215. https://books.google.com/books?id=ea6aAJ01TRkC&pg=PA215&lpg=PA215&dq=%22archer+mathews%22+%22general+assembly%22+virginia&source=bl&ots=P3DYBHzamc&sig=7eQ4v9M4q3Ipu3Xy58b73GFk-v8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pmOHUJahGoLM9gT8uoGIDg&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22archer%20mathews%22%20%22general%20assembly%22%20virginia&f=false Retrieved October 23, 2012</ref> **William Mathews (1741–1772), Justice of the Peace in [[Botetourt County]] 1770–1772. Son of John Mathews <ref name=VSL /> ***John Mathews (1768–1849), Virginia Delegate from Greenbrier County 1798–1802; Clerk of Greenbrier County Court 1831–1849. Son of William Mathews.<ref name=Callahan>Callahan, James Morton (1923). "History of West Virginia, old and new, in one volume, and West Virginia biography, in two additional volumes (1923)." Chicago, IL: The American Historical Society: v.2. http://www23.us.archive.org/stream/historyofgreenbr00cole/historyofgreenbr00cole_djvu.txt Retrieved November 2, 2012</ref> ***James William Mathews (d. 1825), Virginia Delegate from Greenbrier County 1802. [[Major (United States)|Major]] in the United States Army 1812. Son of William Mathews.<ref name="Lexington" /> ***Joseph Mathews (1770–1834), Son of William Mathews ****[[Mason Mathews]] (1803–1878), Sheriff of Lewisburg 1825–1828, Justice of the Peace in Lewisburg 1827–1849; Commissioner of the Revenue for Lewisburg 1830–1832; Virginia Delegate from Greenbrier County 1859–1865. He married Eliza Shore Reynolds (1808–1872), sister of [[Alexander W. Reynolds]] (1817–1876), [[Brigadier General (CSA)|Brigadier General]] in the [[Confederate States Army]]. Son of Joseph Mathews<ref name="McClinton">McClintic, Judge George W., "Archer, Mathews and Others", - article in the West Virginia News, June 16, 1938, on the 160th anniversary of Greenbrier County, quoted in University of VA, "The Renicks of Greenbrier," by bf Harlow Jr. (Lexington, VA, 1951)</ref> *****[[Henry Mason Mathews]] (1834–1884), delegate to the 1872 West Virginia State Convention; [[List of Attorneys General of West Virginia|Attorney General of West Virginia]] 1873–1977; [[Governor of West Virginia]] 1877–1881. Captain of Engineers in the Confederate States Army 1861–1863; [[Major (US)|Major]] of Artillery 1863–1864. Son of Mason Mathews.<ref name="Combs, James Thurl">Combs, James Thurl (1987). "Greenbrier, C.S.A. Wartime Letters of Mason Mathews to his son Captain Joseph William Mathews, C.S.A." ''The Journal of the Greenbrier Historical Society'' ([[Parsons, West Virginia]]: Greenbrier Historical Society) V (1): 5–44.</ref><ref name=White /> ******[[William Gordon Mathews]] (1877–1923), Referee of Bankruptcy for [[Kanawha, West Virginia]] 1898–1908, [[Clerk of court|Clerk of Court]] for Kanawha, West Virginia 1903–1904. Democratic Candidate for the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals 1908. <ref name=Atkinson>Atkinson, George W. (1919). Bench and Bar of West Virginia. Harvard University:Virginia law book company https://books.google.com/books?id=qi8aAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA279&dq=%22william+gordon+mathews%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22william%20gordon%20mathews%22&f=false Retrieved December 9, 2012</ref> *****[[Alexander Ferdinand Mathews]] (1838–1906), Captain and Assistant Commissary of Subsistence in the Confederate States Army 1861–1865. [[West Virginia University]] [[Board of Regents]] 1871-1881. Son of Mason Mathews.<ref name="Combs, James Thurl" /><ref name="Greenbrier Historical Society">Greenbrier Historical Society (1938) Greenbrier Historical Society Historical Booklet, Greenbrier Co., 1938. http://www.lewisburg.org/history/mathewsbio.htm Retrieved 2012-10-19</ref> *****Joseph William Mathews (1841–1897), Captain in the Confederate States Army 1861–1863; [[Assistant Adjutant General]] 1863–1865. Son of Mason Mathews.<ref name="Combs, James Thurl" /> *****Virginia Amanda Mathews. Daughter of Mason Mathews.<ref name="Combs, James Thurl" /> ****** [[Mason Mathews Patrick]] (1863–1942), [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] and Chief of Air Service of the American Expeditionary Force 1918–1921; Chief of [[US Army Air Service]] 1921–1926; [[United States Army Air Corps|Chief of US Army Air Corps]] 1926–1927 in the United States Army. Public Utilities Commissioner for the District of Columbia 1929-1933. Son of Virginia Amanda Mathews.<ref name="West Virginia Daily News">West Virginia Daily News(1967, June 7). Two distinguished soldiers native sons of Greenbrier county: World War Heroes of Greenbrier to be Honored in Special Exercises of 160th Anniversary Celebration. West Virginia Daily News.</ref><ref name=Arlington>Mason Mathews Patrick: Major General, United States Army(2010). Retrieved November 2, 2012 from http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/mpatrick.htm</ref> {{hidden end}}{{clear}}
== Other Mathews of Virginia == [[File:Genmathews.jpg|thumb|right|[[Thomas Mathews (politician)|Thomas Mathews]] (1742–1812), 7th [[List of Speakers of the Virginia House of Delegates|Speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates]]]] There have been scattered other Mathews who have played a role in the public life of Virginia. These include: [[Samuel Mathews|Lt. Col. Samuel Mathews]] (1630–1660), a [[colonial governor of Virginia|commonwealth governor of Virginia]], who died while in office (1656-1660), was a member of the first branch of the Mathews family to settle in the [[New World]] when his father, [[Samuel Matthews|Captain Samuel Matthews]] arrived in Jamestown from England around 1622.<ref name="Meyers">Meyers, Virginia M. and Dorman, John F. (1987). ''Adventurers of Purse and Person, Virginia''. Order of First Families of Virginia</ref> [[Mathews County, Virginia]], named for the family and home to their residence Mathews Manor, later known as [[Denbigh Plantation Site|Denbigh Plantation]].
[[Thomas Mathews (politician)|Thomas Mathews]] (1742–1812), a [[Speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates]], was born in [[Saint Kitts]], an island of the [[West Indies]], and came to the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont region]] of Virginia in the years before the American Revolution. Both Samuel and Thomas Mathews have been connected to the Mathews of Augusta County by some historians,<ref name=Boots/><ref name=Lexington>''Lexington Gazette'' (1938). "Capt. John Mathews and his Descendants." 1738–1938. Bi-centennial Issue: Commemorating the Settlement of the Rockbridge Section of Virginia by the White Men. A Tribute to the Scotch-Irish Pioneers. Lexington Gazette (Virginia)</ref><ref name = Harris>Harris, J.D. (1901) "General Thomas Mathews". ''The Virginia Law Register'', Vol. 7, No. 3 (July 1901), pp. 153–158 https://www.jstor.org/stable/1100495 Retrieved October 25, 2013</ref> though the connection has not been noted by others.<ref name=Boots/><ref name=WashingtonLee/><ref name=Meyers/>
Robert Israel Mathews (1836-1888), a Confederate soldier in the [[American Civil War]], was born in [[Warren County, Virginia]] in 1836./ Robert Israel Mathews was a farmer until the American Civil War broke out. He enlisted in the [[49th Virginia Infantry|49th Virginia Infantry regiment]] in the Confederate Army, which was commanded by [[William Smith (Virginia governor)|William Smith]]. The regiment was nicknamed, "Extra Billy Smith's Boys" in 1861. Robert fought in the [[First Battle of Bull Run|Battle of First Manassas]], [[Battle of Antietam]], [[Battle of Fredericksburg]], [[Second Battle of Bull Run|Battle of Second Bull Run]], [[Battle of Gettysburg]], [[Battle of Chancellorsville]], and the [[Battle of the Wilderness]] where he would be shot through the jaw. After the war, Robert told stories to his children and his grandchildren, one of the stories thought to be of the [[Historic Fairfax County Courthouse|Fairfax Court House]] in 1861 and [[John Quincy Marr]]. After his death in 1888, his grandchildren found a pair of boots he wore and the grandchildren donated them to the Front Royal Civil War Museum in [[Front Royal, Virginia]]. He was buried in [[Browntown, Albemarle County, Virginia|Browntown, Virginia]].{{clear}}
