revision.text:
{{Infobox Native American leader | name = Mo-nah-se-tah | image = File:Monahsetah.jpg | image_size = | caption = | tribe = [[Cheyenne people|Cheyenne]] | lead = | birth_date = c. 1850 | birth_place = | death_date = 1922 | death_place = | predecessor = | successor = | native_name = [[Cheyenne language|Cheyenne]]: Monâhtseta'e, Mo-nah-see-tah ("Spring Grass"), Meotxi, Me-o-tzi | nicknames = | known_for = Taken captive by the [[7th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|7th U.S. Cavalry]] under the command of Lt. Colonel (brevet Major General) [[George Armstrong Custer]] after the [[Battle of Washita River]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | rp_coordinates = | religion = | party = | education = | spouse = | partner = [[George Armstrong Custer]] (?) | children = Son, Yellow Bird, and a second child (?) | parents = Father, [[Little Rock (Cheyenne chief)|Little Rock]] | relations = | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Mo-nah-se-tah''' or '''Mo-nah-see-tah'''Recorded to mean "Spring Grass". The name may possibly be '''''Monâhtseta'e''''', which might mean "Shoot Woman"—"shoot" as in "the young grass that shoots in the spring." See [http://www.fortunecity.com/victorian/song/1147/names/names2.htm Cheyenne Names] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20001007005004/http://www.fortunecity.com/victorian/song/1147/names/names2.htm |date=2000-10-07 }} by Wayne Leman. (c. 1850 - 1922), aka '''Me-o-tzi''',Recorded to mean "Spring Grass". The name may possibly be '''''Meoohtse'e'''''. Meaning unknown. See [http://www.fortunecity.com/victorian/song/1147/names/names2.htm Cheyenne Names] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20001007005004/http://www.fortunecity.com/victorian/song/1147/names/names2.htm |date=2000-10-07 }} by Wayne Leman. was the daughter of the [[Cheyenne]] [[Council of Forty-four|chief]] [[Little Rock (Cheyenne chief)|Little Rock]]. Her father was killed on November 28, 1868, in the [[Battle of Washita River]] when the camp of Chief [[Black Kettle]], of which Little Rock was a member, was attacked by the [[7th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|7th U.S. Cavalry]] under the command of Lt. Colonel (brevet Major General) [[George Armstrong Custer]].Greene 2004, p. 120. Mo-nah-se-tah was among the 53 Cheyenne women and children taken captive by the 7th Cavalry after the battle.Greene 2004, p. 169. Allegedly, according to Captain [[Frederick Benteen]], chief of scouts Ben Clark, and Cheyenne oral history, Custer had a sexual relationship with the 18-year-old Mo-nah-se-tah during the winter and early spring of 1868-1869.Utley 2001, p. 107. Mo-nah-se-tah gave birth to a child in January 1869, two months after the Washita battle; Cheyenne oral history alleges that she later bore a second child, fathered by Custer, in late 1869. Custer, however, had apparently become sterile after contracting venereal disease at West Point, leading some historians to believe that the father was really his brother [[Thomas Custer|Thomas]]. ==Battle of the Washita== {{main|Battle of Washita River}} At daybreak on November 27, 1868, the 7th U.S. Cavalry under the command of Lt. Colonel George Custer attacked a Cheyenne camp of 51 lodges on the Washita River in Indian Territory (present-day Oklahoma). Custer's troops were able to take control of the village quickly, but it took longer to quell all remaining resistance.Greene 2004, pp 116-138. Although some women and children were killed, as Custer acknowledged in his report of the battle,"In the excitement of the fight, as well as in self-defense, some of the squaws and a few of the children were killed." Custer, George Armstrong. (1868-11-28). Report to Maj. Gen. P.H. Sheridan. In [http://www.1st-hand-history.org/Exdocs/Exdoc18/album1.html U.S. Senate 1869] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014236/http://www.1st-hand-history.org/Exdocs/Exdoc18/album1.html |date=2007-09-28 }}, pp. 27-29; [http://www.1st-hand-history.org/Congress/hd240/ALBUM4.HTML U.S. House of Representatives 1870] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014229/http://www.1st-hand-history.org/Congress/hd240/ALBUM4.HTML |date=2007-09-28 }}, pp. 162-165. Reproduced in Cozzens 2003, pp. 394-397; Hardorff 2006, pp. 60-65. Chief of scouts Ben Clark estimated as many as 75 women and children killed. Clark, Ben. (1899-05-14). "Custer's Washita Fight" (interview). ''New York Sun''. Reproduced in Hardoff 2006, pp. 204-215; casualty estimate on p. 208. For details on casualty estimates, see [[Battle of Washita River#Indian casualties at the Washita|Indian casualties at the Washita]]. some measures were taken to protect noncombatants, with troops directed to take women and children who had been captured to a designated lodge in the village to be held under guard as the battle continued. One of the scouts, Raphael Romero, was sent to assure those women and children who had remained in their lodges during the attack that they would not be harmed.Green 2004, pp. 120, 189-190. A total of fifty-three women and children were taken captive. ==Account by White Cow Bull (Lakota)== In 1938, Joseph White Cow Bull, an [[Oglala Sioux|Oglala]] [[Lakota people|Lakota]] veteran of the [[Battle of the Little Bighorn]], went with [[David Humphreys Miller]] to the Little Bighorn battlefield and recounted to him his recollections of the battle. Among his recollections:Miller, 1971.
While we were together in this village [on the [[Little Bighorn River]]], I spent most of my time with the ''Shahiyela'' [Cheyenne] since I knew their tongue and their ways almost as well as my own. In all those years I had never taken a wife, although I had had many women. One woman I wanted was a pretty young ''Shahiyela'' named Monahseetah, or Meotxi as I called her. She was in her middle twenties but had never married any man of her tribe. Some of my ''Shahiyela'' friends said she was from the southern branch of their tribe, just visiting up north, and they said no ''Shahiyela'' could marry her because she had a seven-year-old son born out of wedlock and that tribal law forbade her getting married. They said the boy’s father had been a white soldier chief named Long Hair; he had killed her father, Chief Black Kettle {{sic}}, in a battle in the south [Battle of the Washita] eight winters before, they said, and captured her. He had told her he wanted to make her his second wife, and so he had her. But after a while his first wife, a white woman, found her out and made him let her go.
Miller asked White Cow Bull, "Was this boy still with her here?" and White Cow Bull answered:
Yes, I saw him often around the ''Shahiyela'' camp. He was named Yellow Bird and he had light streaks in his hair. He was always with his mother in the daytime, so I would have to wait until night to try to talk to her alone. She knew I wanted to walk with her under a courting blanket and make her my wife. But she would only talk with me through the tepee cover and never came outside.
==Notes== {{reflist|3}} ==References== * Brill, Charles J. (2002). ''Conquest of the Southern Plains; Uncensored Narrative of the Battle of the Washita and Custer's Southern Campaign''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press. {{ISBN|0-8061-3416-X}}. Originally published in 1938 (Oklahoma City, OK: Golden Saga Publishers). * Cozzens, Peter, ed. (2003). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ftb3spzLngkC&pg=PP1&ots=t-Ef7-iVMf&dq=isbn:0811700194&sig=f472coHiyy70p1pdsdcEgnidaZU Eyewitnesses to the Indian Wars, Volume Three: Conquering the Southern Plains.]'' Mechanicsburg, PA: Stackpole Books. {{ISBN|0-8117-0019-4}}. * Custer, George Armstrong. (1874). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=f1ReLxHwN_YC&dq=%22my+life+on+the+plains%22+custer&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=5P9x1dXi85&sig=34Fn6j_ppCTRdr_fi4nvZKX3Pc0 My Life on the Plains: Or Personal Experiences With the Indians.]'' New York: Sheldon and Company. Also available online [http://www.kancoll.org/books/custerg/ from Kansas Collection Books]. * Greene, Jerome A. (2004). ''Washita, The Southern Cheyenne and the U.S. Army.'' Campaigns and Commanders Series, vol. 3. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press. {{ISBN|0-8061-3551-4}}. * Hardorff, Richard G., compiler & editor (2006). ''Washita Memories: Eyewitness Views of Custer's Attack on Black Kettle's Village''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press. {{ISBN|0-8061-3759-2}}. * Hoig, Stan. (1980). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=esuewT_lSwwC&dq=%22the+battle+of+the+washita%22+hoig&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=avQxt-3IkB&sig=8mxP1c5ZAyeLy82ltH6obQISgqU The Battle of the Washita: The Sheridan-Custer Indian Campaign of 1867-69.]'' Lincoln, NE: University of Nebraska Press. {{ISBN|0-8032-7204-9}}. Previously published in 1976 (Garden City, NY: Doubleday). {{ISBN|0-385-11274-2}}. * Miller, David Humphreys. (1971). [http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1971/4/1971_4_28.shtml "Echoes of the Little Bighorn."] ''American Heritage Magazine'' 22(4), June 1971. With an epilogue by [[Robert M. Utley]]. * Utley, Robert M. (2001). ''Cavalier in Buckskin: George Armstrong Custer and the Western Military Frontier,'' rev. ed. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press. {{ISBN|0-8061-3387-2}}. * Welch, James with Paul Stekler (2007 [1994]). ''Killing Custer: The Battle of Little Bighorn and the Fate of the Plains Indians''. New York: Norton Paperback (W. W. Norton & Company). {{ISBN|978-0-393-32939-1}}. * Wert, Jeffry D. (1997). ''Custer: The Controversial Life of George Armstrong Custer''. New York: Simon & Schuster. {{ISBN|0-684-83275-5}}. {{DEFAULTSORT:Mo-Nah-Se-Tah}} [[Category:Cheyenne people]] [[Category:1850s births]] [[Category:1922 deaths]] [[Category:George Armstrong Custer]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Nancy Dell'Olio | image = Dellollioerotica.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Dell'Olio, London, November 2011 | birth_name = Nancy Dell'Olio | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|8|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | nationality = | years_active = | occupation = Lawyer | television = ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' (2011)
''[[Celebrity Big Brother 17|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' (2016) | partner = [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] (1997–2007)
[[Trevor Nunn]] (2011) }} '''Nancy Dell'Olio''' (born 23 August 1961) is an Italian-British lawyer who first came to public notice as the girlfriend of [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]]. ==Early life== Dell'Olio was born in New York in 1961{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2029983/Nancy-Dell-Olio-showcases-jaw-droppingly-youthful-body-celebrates-50th-birthday.html|title=Nancy Delio ... celebrates 50th birthday|publisher= Daily Mail|date=25 August 2011|accessdate=14 October 2011|location=London|first=Marcus|last=Barnes}} where her mother Antonia was born and her immigrant father ran a series of delicatessens. She is the eldest of four children; when she was five her family moved back to Italy, to the town of [[Bisceglie]] in the [[Province of Barletta-Andria-Trani]] and region of [[Apulia]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/jun/08/sport.comment1|title=The Observer Profile: Nancy Dell'Olio – Sven's star striker|publisher=The Guardian|date=8 June 2003|accessdate=14 October 2011|location=London|first=Harriet|last=Lane}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1393777/Nancy-DellOlio-comes-clean-age-takes-Sir-Trevor-Nunn-romantic-break-Italy.html|title='I'm almost 50!' Nancy Dell'Olio comes clean about her age as she takes Sir Trevor Nunn for another romantic break in Italy|publisher=Daily Mail|date=3 June 2011|accessdate=14 October 2011|location=London|first=Jody|last=Thompson}} ==Projects== In 2005, Dell'Olio hosted the show ''Footballers' Cribs'' on MTV. She gave viewers tours of the luxury homes of English football players. "Nancy is a dream signing for us," said series executive producer Sean Murphy. "She's the first lady of football, so is in the perfect position to give us a real insider's view."{{cite web |url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/2005/06/10/nancydellolio |title=Nancy Dell'Olio to peek into footballers' homes |work=Hello! |date=10 June 2005 |accessdate=24 September 2011}} In June 2007, Dell'Olio had an autobiography published titled ''My Beautiful Game,'' better known in publishing circles as ''My Life On The Game''.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2007/jun/24/biography.features1|title=Nancy scores again – Book review (My beautiful game by Nancy Dell'Olio)|publisher=The Guardian|date=24 June 2007|accessdate=14 October 2011|location=London|first=Lisa|last=O'Kelly}} In December 2008, Dell'Olio was interviewed on the BBC news analysis programme ''[[Newsnight]]'' to talk about a new range of lingerie she was launching but, according to interviewer [[Jeremy Paxman]], "I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about".{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h_vqdRkv7LI |title=Newsnight |date=21 January 2010 |location=London}} The programme swiftly moved on to the next item. In 2011, Dell'Olio took part in the [[Strictly Come Dancing (series 9)|ninth series]] of BBC1 show ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]''.{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-14809342 | title=Strictly Come Dancing signs up Lulu and Edwina Currie | publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation | work=BBC News | date=6 September 2011 | accessdate=6 September 2011}} On 30 October, she and partner [[Anton du Beke]] were eliminated.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/strictly-come-dancing/8858765/Nancy-DellOlio-knocked-out-of-Strictly-Come-Dancing.html |title=Nancy Dell'Olio knocked out of Strictly Come Dancing |work=The Telegraph |first=Michael |last=Hogan |date=30 October 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011 |location=London}} The [[Daily Telegraph]] reported that Dell'Olio clod-hopped around the show. Dell'Olio reported it as "The best season Strictly ever had; everyone say so".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/edinburgh-festival/11031284/Nancy-DellOlio-Its-the-job-of-a-woman-to-look-impeccable.html |title=Nancy Dell'Olio: 'It's the job of a woman to look impeccable' |work=The Telegraph |date=14 August 2014 |location=London}} On 23 February 2012, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' announced that Dell'Olio would begin contributing to its Sunday editions.{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/4147345/Your-Sunday-service.html |title=Your Sunday service. Nancy Dell'Olio joins The Sun on Sunday team Just three days to go... |newspaper=The Sun (United Kingdom) |date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=23 February 2012 |location=London |first=Chris |last=Pollard}} Dell'Olio presented her own one-woman show, co-scripted by comedian Diane Spencer, called Rainbows from Diamonds at Edinburgh Fringe in 2014. On 5 January 2016, it was revealed that Dell'Olio would be one of the sixteen housemates competing in the [[Celebrity Big Brother 17|seventeenth series]] of ''[[Celebrity Big Brother (UK TV series)|Celebrity Big Brother]]''. She entered on Day 1.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3385311/PICTURED-Strictly-siren-Kristina-Rihanoff-Kim-Kardashian-s-BFF-Jonathan-Cheban-troubled-Danniella-Westbrook-confirmed-Celebrity-Big-Brother.html|title=Strictly siren Kristina Rihanoff, Kim Kardashian's BFF Jonathan Cheban and troubled Danniella Westbrook among 16 stars confirmed for Celebrity Big Brother|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=5 January 2016|accessdate=5 January 2016|first=Lucy|last=Mapstone}} She became the second housemate to be evicted on Day 11. In late January 2016, Dell'Olio was interviewed by the [[Daily Telegraph]], in which she mentioned she was starting her own brand of [[limoncello]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/12120751/From-Svens-squeeze-to-start-up-boss-Nancy-DellOlio-on-her-new-limoncello-business.html |title=From Sven's squeeze to start-up boss: Nancy Dell'Olio on her new limoncello business |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=25 January 2016 | location=London }} Dell'Olio aimed to start her new company through crowd funding investment, though only €1,865 of the required €70,000 was raised. The project went ahead. Dell'Olio's aim was not to be involved in the day-to-day running of the company, but only to act as ambassador for it. ==Charity works== Dell'Olio has visited [[British Red Cross]] projects in the UK and in Kenya. She stated, "I have always been a great admirer of the principles and values behind the work of the Red Cross. The thing that really impressed me is that the Red Cross seems to go everywhere, more than any other charity."{{cite web |url=http://www.redcross.org.uk/standard.asp?id=80098 |title=Nancy Dell'Olio |work=BritishRedCross |accessdate=24 September 2011}} Dell'Olio is the chairwoman of Truce International, the British-based charity she founded with Eriksson, which aims to use football as a means of uniting people in areas affected by war.[http://www.truce.net/ Truce – Peace Through The Passion For Football] Dell'Olio is a member of the [[Accademia Apulia|Accademia Apulia UK]].{{cite web |url=http://www.accademiapulia.org/en/members/ |title=Members |work=accademiapulia.org |accessdate=24 September 2011}} ==Personal life== In May 1998, Dell'Olio was introduced to [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], the manager of the [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio football team]], and they began a relationship six months later. In 2001, Eriksson became [[England national football team manager|manager of the England team]], and he and Dell'Olio relocated to [[London]]. In early 2002, Eriksson had a short-lived affair with television presenter [[Ulrika Jonsson]], but he returned to Dell'Olio. In August 2004, Eriksson had an affair with [[The Football Association]] secretary [[Faria Alam]].{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1040809/asp/atleisure/story_3601808.asp | location=Calcutta, India | work=The Telegraph | first=Amit | last=Roy | title=Faria drags Salman into Sven sleaze fest | date=9 August 2004}} As Alam had also had an affair with FA CEO, [[Mark Palios]], when the media got hold of the story, it became high-profile and made leading headlines in newspapers and on television. Dell'Olio was upset but chose to stay with Eriksson. The couple eventually split up in August 2007. {{As of|2011|May}} Dell'Olio was in a relationship with [[Trevor Nunn|Sir Trevor Nunn]],{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/8485598/Sven-Goran-Erikssons-former-lover-Nancy-DellOlio-insists-Im-drawn-to-men-of-passion.html |title=Sven-Goran Eriksson's former lover Nancy Dell'Olio insists: 'I'm drawn to men of passion' |newspaper=The Telegraph |first1=Tim |last1=Walker |first2=Richard |last2=Eden |date=1 May 2011 |accessdate=24 September 2011 |location=London}} but by the end of the year it was reported the relationship had ended. In December 2011 she lost a High Court libel action against [[Associated Newspapers]], publishers of the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' newspaper, over an article that referred to her as a "man eater".{{cite news|title=Nancy Dell'Olio loses court action over "man eater" newspaper comments|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/8969499/Nancy-DellOlio-loses-court-action-over-man-eater-newspaper-comments..html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=December 20, 2011}} In June 2016, Dell'Olio was photographed at a fashion show in [[Hyde Park, London]] with taut new features and not looking like her former self, five months after she had appeared on Celebrity Big Brother. In the words of the [[Daily Mirror]], "she looks unrecognisable".{{cite news| url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/nancy-dellolio-looks-unrecognisable-shows-8092415 | location=Hyde Park, London | work=The Daily Mirror | title=Nancy Dell'Olio looks unrecognisable as she shows off taut features during fashion show | date=2 June 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=1674457|name = Nancy Dell'Olio}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dell'Olio, Nancy}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lawyers from New York City]] [[Category:People from the Province of Barletta-Andria-Trani]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:1961 births]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox military person | name = Nathaniel Gray Smith Hart
''also'' Nathaniel G. S. Hart{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149–150]}} | image = | caption = | birth_date = circa 1784{{sfn|Kleber|1992||pages=[http://www.kyenc.org/entry/h/HARTN01.html 415–416]}} | death_date = {{Death date|1813|01|23}} (aged 29) | birth_place = [[Hagerstown, Maryland]] | death_place = Michigan | placeofburial = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] (originally)
Re-interred at State Cemetery/[[Frankfort Cemetery]] in [[Frankfort, Kentucky]] in 1834{{sfn|Kleber|1992||pages=[http://www.kyenc.org/entry/h/HARTN01.html 415–416]}}{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}}{{sfn|Farmer|1890|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_Od5AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA280#v=onepage&q&f=falsee 280]}} | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | birth_name = | allegiance = United States | branch = | serviceyears = 1812–13 | rank = [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] | servicenumber = | unit = Lexington Light Infantry | commands = Lexington Light Infantry
Deputy Inspector for Left Wing of Northwestern Army | battles = [[War of 1812]] * [[Battle of Frenchtown|Battle of Frenchtown, Battle of River Raisin]] | battles_label = | awards = | relations = Lucretia Hart Clay, [[Henry Clay]] | laterwork = | signature = }} '''Nathaniel Gray Smith Hart''' (c. 1784 – January 23, 1813), often '''Nathaniel G. S. Hart,''' {{efn-ua|Although some sources list Hart's name as "Nathaniel G. T. Hart," this is incorrect according to historian John E. Kleber writing in ''The Kentucky Encyclopedia''{{sfn|Kleber|1992||pages=[http://www.kyenc.org/entry/h/HARTN01.html 415–416]}} and to historians David and Jeanne Heidler's ''Encyclopedia of the War of 1812''.{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}} Also, Hart is referred to in a court document dating from shortly before his death as "Nathaniel G. S. Hart."{{sfn|Cook|Cummings|1985|page=[http://simpsonhistory.com/notes/thomashart3.html 185]}} The misnomer apparently dates to a mistake in ''Historical Sketches of Kentucky'', either the Richard Collins edition (published in 1874) or the original edition (published in 1848 by Lewis Collins).{{sfn|Collins|1848|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=XFlAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA345#v=onepage&q&f=false 345]}}}} was a [[Lexington, Kentucky]] lawyer and businessman, who served with the state's volunteer militia during the War of 1812. As [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] of the Lexington Light Infantry from Kentucky, Hart and many of his men were killed in the [[River Raisin Massacre#River Raisin Massacre|River Raisin Massacre]] of January 23, 1813, after being taken prisoner the day before following the [[Battle of Frenchtown]] in [[Michigan Territory]]. Hart was especially well-connected politically and socially. In addition to reading law with [[Henry Clay]], Hart's wife Anna and Clay's wife Lucretia were sisters. Hart's wife Anna Edward Gist was the stepdaughter of Charles Scott, Governor of Kentucky and through her Hart was also a brother-in-law to James Brown, a future Ambassador to France and to James Pindell - a member of the Society of Cincinnati. Many other members of Hart's Kentucky militia unit and its associated troops also came from the elite of Lexington and of the state. The men's deaths in the two Battles of Frenchtown, but especially in the subsequent Massacre captured state and national attention. The phrase "Remember the Raisin!" became an American call to arms for the duration of the War. ==Personal life== [[File:Henry Clay's law office.jpg|thumb|[[Henry Clay's Law Office|Henry Clay's law office]] in Lexington]] Nathaniel Hart was one of seven children,{{sfn|Remini|1992|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=f9Hb6i90_mAC&pg=PA29#v=onepage&q&f=false 29]}} the second son of Colonel Thomas Hart, a veteran of the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], and his wife Susanna (Gray) Hart.{{sfn|Smith|Clay|Clay|1899|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=72gUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232]}} Originally from [[North Carolina]], the family had moved to [[Hagerstown, Maryland]], where Nathaniel was born. In 1794 they settled in [[Lexington, Kentucky]] as part of the postwar migration west. His father was a highly successful businessman, achieving wealth. Hart's four sisters married men who achieved some renown: Ann married the future US Senator [[James Brown (Louisiana)|James Brown]] (who subsequently served as [[United States Ambassador to France#United States Ministers Plenipotentiary to France|Minister to France]]); Eliza married the surgeon Dr. Richard Pindell (a member of the [[Society of the Cincinnati]]);{{cite journal|title=A Militant Surgeon of the Revolution:Some Letters of Richard Pindell, M.D.|journal=Maryland Historical Magazine |publisher=[[Maryland Historical Society]]|date=1922|volume=17-18|page=309|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5woSAQAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA309#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=January 26, 2015}}{{sfn|Williams|1992|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3AV5AAAAMAAJ 427]}} Susanna married the lawyer Samuel Price, and Lucretia married [[Henry Clay]], future US Senator and Secretary of State.{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149–150]}}{{sfn|Connelley|Coulter|1922||page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=7DMVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA5#v=onepage&q&f=false 5]}} Hart attended [[Princeton University|Princeton College]], where his classmates included William Elliott from western Ontario. Elliott's father was a Loyalist who had resettled in Canada after the Revolutionary War.{{sfn|Berton|2011|page=406}} The two young men were close enough that Elliot stayed with Hart's parents for a time to recover from a serious illness.{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}} After Hart's return to Lexington, he [[read law]] under Henry Clay, passed the bar, and set up a law practice in the city.{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149]}} Like his father, he became a successful businessman,{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}} a ropewalk (hemp rope factory) in the city being among his ventures. Hemp was a commodity crop of central Kentucky.{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149–150]}} In April 1809, Hart married Anna Edward Gist,{{sfn|Kleber|1992||pages=[http://www.kyenc.org/entry/h/HARTN01.html 415–416]}} the stepdaughter of [[Charles Scott (governor)|General Charles Scott]], [[governor of Kentucky]], and daughter of Judith Cary Gist Scott and her late husband General [[Nathaniel Gist]].{{cite book|title=Register of Kentucky State Historical Society, Volume 16|year=1918|publisher=[[Kentucky Historical Society]]|page=59|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XXIUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA58#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=October 22, 2011}} Hart and Anna had two sons, Thomas Hart Jr. and Henry Clay Hart.{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149–150]}}{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}}{{sfn|Smith|Clay|Clay|1899|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=72gUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232]}} On January 7, 1812, Hart [[duel]]led with Samuel E. Watson at a location on the [[Indiana]] side of the [[Ohio River]], near where [[Silver Creek (Ohio River)|Silver Creek]] emptied into the river. This was the site where Henry Clay had duelled with fellow state legislator [[Humphrey Marshall (politician)|Humphrey Marshall]] in 1809.{{cite web|title=The Duels at Silver Creek (Historical Series of New Albany) |url=http://nafclibrary.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/3.08-Duels-at-Silver-Creek.pdf |work=Historical Series of New Albany (Volume III, No. 8) |publisher=New Albany Floyd County Public Library (originally broadcast on "Radio Station WLRP-1570 AM [which] was licensed to operate in New Albany in 1949 and was located at 1570 Clifton Avenue. By 1960, it became WOWI and later in the 1960s, it became WHEL and played country music" and is now [[WLRS (AM)]] |accessdate=April 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409204745/http://nafclibrary.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/3.08-Duels-at-Silver-Creek.pdf |archivedate=April 9, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|title=New Albany Suburb Famous Field of Honor in Early Days |url=http://nafclibrary.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/fieldofhonor.pdf |author=Samuel Scott (New Albany Rotary Club) |year=c. 1950s |work= |publisher=New Albany Floyd County Public Library |accessdate=April 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409212152/http://nafclibrary.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/fieldofhonor.pdf |archivedate=April 9, 2015 |df= }}{{sfn|Hopkins|1959|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=76bJUn8VJWIC&pg=PA613#v=onepage&q&f=false 613]}} ==Military service and death== At the start of the [[War of 1812]], Hart was commissioned as [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] of the Lexington Light Infantry Company (aka "The Silk Stocking Boys"){{sfn|Smith|Clay|Clay|1899|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=72gUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232]}} {{sfn|Ranck|1872|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qidAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q&f=false 156]}} a volunteer unit of the [[Fayette County, Kentucky]] militia.{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149–150]}} He later served as either a Deputy Inspector{{sfn|Kleber|1992||pages=[http://www.kyenc.org/entry/h/HARTN01.html 415–416]}} or as Inspector General of [[William Henry Harrison]]'s [[Army of the Northwest (United States)|Army of the Northwest]].{{cite book|title=Register of the Kentucky State Historical Society, Volume 11(Issue 31)|year=1912–1913|page=19|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UAg8AAAAIAAJ&pg=RA2-PA19#v=onepage&q&f=false}}{{efn-ua|Henry Clay (The papers of Henry Clay, Volume 1, Page 19) refers to Hart's rank as "Inspector General of the N.W.[Northwestern] Army."}} Hart's command was attached to the Fifth Regiment of the Kentucky Volunteer Militia and left for the Northwest in August 1812,{{sfn|Ranck|1872|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qidAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA157#v=onepage&q&f=false 155]}} where it became part of Army of the Northwest under [[James Winchester|General James Winchester]]. In January 1813, a detachment was sent to the defense of [[Frenchtown, Michigan|Frenchtown, Michigan Territory]] as part of an effort to retake Detroit from the British. Frenchtown residents had sent word to the Americans asking for relief from an occupying force of the British and their Indian allies.{{cite web|title=The History|url=http://www.co.monroe.mi.us/government/departments_offices/museum/docs/River_Raisin_Battlefield_Brochure.pdf|work=River Raisin Battlefield|publisher=City of Monroe, Michigan|accessdate=October 25, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927030210/http://www.co.monroe.mi.us/government/departments_offices/museum/docs/River_Raisin_Battlefield_Brochure.pdf|archivedate=September 27, 2011|df=}} [[File:First Battle of the River Raisin.jpg|thumb|Lewis' River Raisin crossing – First Battle]] During the [[Battle of Frenchtown#First Battle of the River Raisin|First Battle of Frenchtown]] on January 18, 1813, the American forces under Lt. Colonel William Lewis were successful in forcing the retreat of the small British force stationed there. The British commander of the [[Fort Malden]] garrison in Amherstburg, [[Henry Procter (British Army officer)|Colonel Henry Procter]],{{sfn|Ramage|Watkins|2011|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=l4qKA2xglF8C&pg=PA106#v=onepage&q&f=false 105]}} made plans to take back Frenchtown and he ordered troops to the area.{{cite web|last=Ridler|first=Jason|title=Henry Procter (Proctor)|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/henry-procter-proctor/|work=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|publisher=[[Historica Canada|Historica Foundation]]|accessdate=January 27, 2015}} On the morning of January 22, 1813, Procter's forces, including hundreds of Indian warriors, attacked the American troops and overwhelmed the right flank of regulars under Winchester, forcing him and much of the general staff to surrender. The Kentucky militia under the command of [[George Madison|Major George Madison]] on the left flank fought on and thought the flag of truce presented by the enemy was a British flag of surrender.{{sfn|Coles|1966|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=d8ZOFNbhIU0C&pg=PA116#v=onepage&q&f=false 116]}} During this second [[Battle of Frenchtown]], 397 Americans were killed.{{cite book|last1=Upton|first1=Emory|title=Military Policy of the United States (Military History of the United States)|date=1904|publisher=United State Government|page=109|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hJYsAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA109#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=May 12, 2016}}{{sfn|Gardner|1860|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=2flAAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA566#v=onepage&q&f=false 566]}} Hart was wounded and was among the 547 survivors{{sfn|Gardner|1860|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=2flAAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA566#v=onepage&q&f=false 566]}} who surrendered to Procter upon orders of Winchester.{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}}{{sfn|Ranck|1872|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qidAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA256#v=onepage&q&f=false 256]}} Not many more than 30 Kentucky troops escaped death or capture.{{cite web|title=River Raisin National Battlefield Park - Monroe, Michigan|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/cultural_diversity/River_Raisin_National_Battlefield_Park.html|website=nps.gov|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=January 27, 2015}} William Elliott, Hart's former Princeton classmate who had become a [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|Captain in the British Army]], promised the wounded man safe passage to Fort Malden,{{efn-ua|According to ''Pierre Berton's War of 1812'' (Page 406), Elliott's mother was [[Shawnee]] and he was raised among the Indians.{{sfn|Berton|2011|page=406}}}} but did not carry out his pledge.{{sfn|Ranck|1872|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qidAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA256#v=onepage&q&f=false 256]}} Elliot borrowed a horse, bridle and saddle from Major [[Benjamin Franklin Graves]], an American officer, promising to send help to the American wounded, but none arrived.{{sfn|Ranck|1872|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qidAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA255#v=onepage&q&f=false 255]}} Acting American captain William Caldwell wrote the next month that he heard Elliott tell General Winchester and Major Madison that "the Indians were very excellent surgeons (and ought to kill all the officers and men)."{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=William|title=War of 1812 – Caldwell letter (February 20, 1813)|url=http://www.jesshistorical.com/newsletters/Vol2Nr1.pdf#page=6 |format=pdf |work=Jessamine Historical Quarterly|publisher=Jessamine County Historical & Genealogical Society|accessdate=October 25, 2011|page=6|date=January 2003}}{{cite book|title=American State Papers: Documents, Legislative and Executive of the Congress of the United States (Part 5, Volume 1)|year=1832|publisher=[[Gales and Seaton]] (US. Congress)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iJUbAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA375#v=onepage&q&f=false|page = 375|accessdate=October 26, 2011}} In one official letter, the eye-witness says that Elliott's broken promise included an offer to take Hart in Elliott's "own sleigh to [[Fort Malden|Malden]] that evening" and that Hart could stay at Elliott's home for his recovery.{{sfn|Brannan|1823|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ceceAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA135#v=onepage&q&f=false 135–136]}} Unable to march with the able-bodied prisoners who were being directed to Fort Malden, Hart paid a friendly Indian to take him to the fort. Along the way they encountered other Indians, who shot and [[Scalping|scalped]] Hart.{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}}{{sfn|Lossing|1869|pages=[https://archive.org/stream/fieldbookswar181200lossrich#page/358/mode/2up 358–359]}} Hart and an estimated 30–100 unarmed prisoners were killed by Indians on January 23, the day after the battle, in what became known as the [[River Raisin Massacre#River Raisin Massacre|River Raisin Massacre]].{{efn-ua|Elliott reportedly said, "He tried to explain that it is impossible to restrain the Indians and (...) that they are simply seeking revenge for their own losses." (of [[Battle of Tippecanoe|Tippecanoe]] and [[Battle of the Mississinewa|Mississinewa]]).{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA149#v=onepage&q&f=false 149–150]}}{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}}{{sfn|Cook|Cummings|1985|pages=[http://simpsonhistory.com/notes/thomashart3.html 185–189]}}{{cite web|title=The Battles of the River Raisin|url=http://www.co.monroe.mi.us/government/departments_offices/museum/the_battles_of_the_river_raisin.html|publisher=City of Monroe, Michigan|accessdate=October 25, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927030302/http://www.co.monroe.mi.us/government/departments_offices/museum/the_battles_of_the_river_raisin.html|archivedate=September 27, 2011|df=}}}} The high fatalities of the Americans in the Battle of Frenchtown and the subsequent Massacre of prisoners became fuel for pro-war political factions known as War Hawks, and for anti-British sentiment of the era.{{sfn|Clift|2009|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=1A3k7Wqaq0wC&pg=PA87149#v=onepage&q&f=false 87–88]}} The phrase "Remember the Raisin!" entered the lexicon of the day as a flashpoint for popular sentiment, becoming a battle cry for American troops, especially the ones on the western frontier.{{cite book|title=Michigan Historical Collections, Volume 7|year=1892|publisher=State of Michigan (Michigan Historical Commission)|page=222|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DqxNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA222#v=onepage&q&f=false|author=Michigan Historical Commission, Michigan State Historical Society, Michigan Pioneer and Historical Society|accessdate=October 26, 2011}} The fact that many of the murdered men were well-known and well-connected members of Kentucky's elite increased the public outcry. Among the dead was [[John Allen (soldier)|Colonel John Allen]], Henry Clay's law-partner and co-counsel in [[Aaron Burr]]'s conspiracy trial at [[Frankfort, Kentucky|Frankfort]].{{sfn|Kleber|1992||page=415}}{{sfn|Kinkead|1896|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=zfETAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA111#v=onepage&q&f=false 111]}} Hart's death is remembered in modern times as "The Murder of Captain Hart."{{cite web|title=Murder of Captain Hart|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=27260|work=HMdb.org|accessdate=October 15, 2011}} Major [[Benjamin Franklin Graves]] of Lexington was another officer apparently killed while a prisoner of the [[Potawatomi]], who were overseeing him and others marching to Detroit. Many American prisoners disappeared or were killed while being force-marched back to British-held territory.{{sfn|Greenblatt|Bowman|2009|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=RFcP4PFvhTUC&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false 72]}}{{sfn|Watson|2014|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Xy5ZAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q&f=false 113]}}{{cite journal|last1=Wyman|first1=(Dr.) Hal C.|title=Remarks on the Surgery of the War of 1812|journal=Physician and Surgeon |date=May 1907|volume=29|issue=5|pages=206–207}}{{sfn|Burcar|2011|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3xcjTa3sRisC&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q&f=false 18]}}{{sfn|Lossing|1869|pages=[https://archive.org/stream/fieldbookswar181200lossrich#page/358/mode/2up 358–359]}} ==Aftermath of Hart's death and memorials== [[File:Cemetery, Military Monument-3 cropped.jpg|thumb|Names of some of the American officers who died at the Raisin Massacre or afterward, listed on one panel of the Kentucky War Memorial in [[Frankfort Cemetery]] in [[Frankfort, Kentucky]]]] Owing to their high casualties and status as prisoners, surviving Americans were not able to properly bury their fallen comrades.American State Papers, page [https://books.google.com/books?id=iJUbAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA369#v=onepage&q&f=false 369 (Alexis Labadie)] The remains of the American dead at this site were not interred until months later.{{cite book|last=Scroggins|first=William G|title=Leaves of a Stunted Shrub, Volume One|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bt99KfyjpFUC&pg=RA2-PA41#v=onepage&q&f=false| accessdate=October 25, 2011|isbn=9780979125751}} In 1818, the remains were transferred from [[Monroe, Michigan]] to [[Detroit]].{{sfn|Farmer|1890|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_Od5AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA280#v=onepage&q&f=falsee 280]}} Isaac Baker, an American ensign who survived the Massacre and served as an official US Agent for the prisoners, stated in a report to General Winchester that: :The dead of our army are still denied the rites of sepulture. ... I was told the hogs were eating them. A gentleman told me he had seen them running about with skulls, arms, legs and other parts of the human system in their mouths. The French people on the Raisin buried Captains Hart, Woolfolk, and some others, but it was more than their lives were worth to have been caught paying this last customed tribute to mortality."American State Papers, [https://books.google.com/books?id=iJUbAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA370#v=onepage&q&f=false page 370 (Isaac Baker)] In 1834, the box containing the commingled American remains (including [[tomahawk (axe)|tomahawk]]ed skulls), were moved from their former Detroit resting-place and re-interred in Detroit's City Cemetery.{{sfn|Farmer|1890|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_Od5AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA280#v=onepage&q&f=falsee 280]}} These remains are asserted to have received final burial in the [[Frankfort Cemetery|State Cemetery of Frankfort, Kentucky]].{{sfn|Kleber|1992||pages=[http://www.kyenc.org/entry/h/HARTN01.html 415–416]}}{{sfn|Heidler|Heidler|2004| |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_c09EJgek50C&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false 232–233]}} As late as 1849, a mass grave from the battle was excavated during road construction in Monroe, which developed in the area of the battlefield. Some writers state that those skeletons, along with the City Cemetery remains, were returned to Kentucky for final and proper burial that year.{{cite journal|title=Kentucky's Gallant Dead|journal=Niles' National Register|year=1849|volume=74|page=235|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAAQAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA235#v=onepage&q&f=false|editor1-first=William Ogden|editor1-last=Niles}}{{efn-ua|According to Clift's ''Remember the Raisin!'' (Page xii), "Kentucky historians have written that these dead now rest in the state lots at Frankfort Cemetery. ... In the light of present day research, little has been found to substantiate these statements."}} A 2004 archeological investigation at the State Monument found no evidence of remains from men of the River Raisin events.{{cite web|last=Stottman |first=M. Jay |title=Archaeological Investigation of the State Monument – Frankfort, Kentucky |url=http://heritage.ky.gov/NR/rdonlyres/2D6096F9-A3B5-48E2-85CB-E04A99ECA539/0/StateMonument.pdf |publisher=Kentucky Archaeological Survey |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |author2=David Pollack |author3=Peter E. Killoran |author4=Sarah E. Miller |author5=Phillip B. Mink |author6=Christina A. Pappas |author7=Eric Schlarb |author8=Lori Stahlgren |date=August 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413194143/http://heritage.ky.gov/NR/rdonlyres/2D6096F9-A3B5-48E2-85CB-E04A99ECA539/0/StateMonument.pdf |archivedate=April 13, 2015 |df= }} [[Matthew Harris Jouett]], a man who painted noted portraits of [[Thomas Jefferson]], [[George Rogers Clark]] and [[Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette|Lafayette]], was one of the Kentucky volunteers and among the survivors of the River Raisin Massacre. The company payroll of $6000 disappeared during the slaughter. Jouett restored the missing funds to the militia, based on his earnings as a painter. He also painted portraits of his fellow soldiers from memory, including Hart and Colonel Allen.{{sfn|Pennington|Miles|2010|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=sV12204GZC8C&pg=PA172#v=onepage&q&f=false 172]}} ==Legacy and honors== *In 1819, the state of [[Kentucky]] named its 61st county as [[Hart County, Kentucky|Hart County]] in Nathaniel Hart's honor.{{cite web|title=Hart County Chamber of Commerce|url=http://hartcountychamber.com/visithart/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26&Itemid=44|accessdate=October 22, 2011}}{{cite web|title=Kentucky Counties Named in Honor of Military Personnel|url=http://kynghistory.ky.gov/people/ky+counties+named+after+military+persons.htm|work=Kentucky: National Guard History eMuseum|publisher=[[Commonwealth of Kentucky]]|accessdate=October 25, 2011}} *Hart was listed among officers on the Kentucky War Memorial in Frankfort Cemetery in the capital of Frankfort. *In 1904 residents of [[Monroe, Michigan]], which includes much of the area of the battlefield, erected a monument to the Kentuckians who died defending their settlement during the various River Raisin engagements.{{cite book|title=Ohio history, Volume 15|year=1906|publisher=[[Ohio Historical Society]]|pages=141–153|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=peKyAQzpPTYC&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Some unidentified victims were buried here.{{cite web|title=The Battle of River Raisin |url=http://www.riverraisinbattlefield.org/the_battles.htm |publisher=Friends of the River Raisin Battlefield (RiverRaisinBattlefield.Org) |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725042206/http://www.riverraisinbattlefield.org/the_battles.htm |archivedate=July 25, 2008 |df= }} *In 2009, the [[River Raisin National Battlefield Park]] was established, the only such park to commemorate the War of 1812, and one of four battlefield parks in the nation. It had earlier been recognized as a state historic site and was previously listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. ==See also== {{Portal|War of 1812}} *[[Kentucky in the War of 1812]] *[[John Allen (soldier)]] == Notes == {{reflist|group=upper-alpha}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|first1=Pierre |last1=Berton |authorlink1=Pierre Berton |title=Pierre Berton's War of 1812: being a compendium of The invasion of Canada and Flames across the border |location=Toronto |type=Paperback |publisher=[[Anchor Canada]] |date=November 1, 2011 |isbn=0385676484 |page=406 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Brannan|first=John|title=Official Letters of the Military and Naval Officers of the United States, during the War with Great Britain in the years 1812, 13, 14, & 15s|year=1823|publisher=[[Way & Gideon]]|pages=135–136|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ceceAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA135#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=November 8, 2011 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last1=Burcar|first1=Colleen|title=It Happened in Michigan: Remarkable Events That Shaped History|date=2011 |location=Guilford, Conn|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]], [[Globe Pequot Press]]|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3xcjTa3sRisC&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-7627-6024-4 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Clift|first=G. Van Nostrand]]|page=566|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2flAAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA566#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=May 12, 2016 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|first1=Miriam |last1=Greenblatt|first2=John Watson |title=America's First Crisis: The War of 1812|location=Albany, NY |publisher=[[SUNY]], Excelsior Editions Press|page=113|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xy5ZAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q&f=false |date=January 1, 2014 |isbn=1438451342 |accessdate=May 13, 2016 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Thomas John Chew|title=History of Washington County, Maryland: From the Earliest Settlements to the Present Time, Volume 1|origyear=1906|page=427 |publisher=Clearfield Company & Family Line Pub. |year=1992 |location=Hagerstown, Md.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3AV5AAAAMAAJ |ref=harv}} ==External links== * [http://www.nps.gov/rira River Raisin National Battlefield Park], National Park Service * [http://www.co.monroe.mi.us/government/departments_offices/museum/river_raisin_battlefield.html City of Monroe, Michigan "River Raisin Battlefield" Visitor Center/Museum] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150413194143/http://heritage.ky.gov/NR/rdonlyres/2D6096F9-A3B5-48E2-85CB-E04A99ECA539/0/StateMonument.pdf Archaeological Investigation of the State Monument Frankfort, Kentucky] {{Kentucky in the War of 1812}} {{Battles of the War of 1812|state=autocollapse}} {{War of 1812}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hart, Nathaniel G.S.}} [[Category:1784 births]] [[Category:1813 deaths]] [[Category:American military personnel killed in the War of 1812]] [[Category:Duellists]] [[Category:Henry Clay]] [[Category:Kentucky lawyers]] [[Category:People from Hagerstown, Maryland]] [[Category:War of 1812 prisoners of war held by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:American prisoners of war]] [[Category:American lawyers admitted to the practice of law by reading law]]

revision.comment: [r] → [ɾ] in IPA for Spanish [[Help_talk:IPA/Spanish#About_R|per discussion]] and [[Wikipedia:Bot_requests#%5Br%5D_%E2%86%92_%5B%C9%BE%5D_in_IPA_for_Spanish|botreq]]
revision.text:
{{Otheruses}}
{{unreferenced|date=August 2016}} {{Wiktionary}} [[File:Picador 1.jpg|250px|thumbnail|Picador in [[Mexico]]]] [[File:Picadores Paseillo.jpg|thumb|Paseillo en la Santa María de Bogotá]] A '''''picador''''' ({{IPA-es|pikaˈðoɾ}}; pl. ''picadores'') is one of the pair of [[horse]]men in a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[bullfight]] that jab the bull with a [[lance]]. They perform in the '''''tercio de varas''''' which is the first of the three stages in a Spanish bullfight.
== Function ==
The picador has three main functions: * To pierce the muscle on the back of the bull’s neck in order to straighten the bull's charge. * To fatigue the bull’s neck muscles and general stamina as it tries to lift the horse with its head. * To lower the bull’s head in preparation for the next stage.
If the public feels that a picador is better than the bull the public will whistle, boo or jeer as they see fit. This is because they do not want the bull to lose all its strength and energy as this can lead to a dull bullfight.
The picador is obliged to give the bull two lances in a first category bullring ([[Barcelona]], [[Madrid]], [[Sevilla]], [[Zaragoza]] etc.), but the [[matador]] may request that the second be waived in second and third category rings. The bull may receive three lances if it is particularly ferocious.
The aim of the bull to charge the picador is often cited as the biggest test of its courage. A bull that does not charge may be punished with a black ''[[Torero#Banderillero|banderilla]]'', which although somewhat longer than a normal ''banderilla'' is largely symbolic and a mark of shame for the breeder. This is very rare.
== History == {{unreferenced section|date=July 2018}} [[File:Picador.JPG|thumb|Picador in action]] Prior to 1928, horses did not wear protection and the bull would on occasion disembowel the horse during this stage. In Seville they retain two teams of ''muleteros'', one to drag out the dead bull and the other to drag out any dead horses (this is now just for tradition). These days the horse is surrounded by a ''peto'', a mattress-like protection that greatly minimizes damage taken. However, injuries to the horses often include broken ribs and damage to internal organs.
In the original days before bullfighting became recognizable in today's form, the picador was the central attraction and his name would be billed on the promotional flyers. In these bullfights the bull would charge the horse and the spectacle was watching the rider's skill in protecting his horse whilst lancing the bull. The picador would lance the bull as many times as necessary. The matador and other bullfighters were on hand to help the picador, to direct the bull to the picador, and finally to finish off the injured bull. It was not until certain foot bullfighters started to bring some flair to their minor roles, to the pleasure of the crowd, that matadors started to become the main attraction, ultimately relegating the picador to a relatively unpopular and minor function.
==See also== {{commonscat|Picadores}} * [[Torero]]
{{Bullfighting}}
[[Category:Bullfighters]] [[Category:Spanish culture]]

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Robert Ryman | image = RYMAN.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Robert Ryman | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age |1930|5|30|}} | birth_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[Painting]], [[Conceptual art]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = [[Mark Rothko]], [[Willem de Kooning]], [[John McLaughlin (artist)|John McLaughlin]], [[Clyfford Still]], [[Jackson Pollock]] and [[Barnett Newman]] | influenced = | awards = }}
'''Robert Ryman''' (born May 30, 1930) is an [[United States|American]] painter identified with the movements of [[monochrome painting]], [[minimalism]], and [[conceptual art]]. He is best known for abstract, white-on-white paintings.<ref>http://www.phillipscollection.org/exhibitions/2010-06-05-exhibition-robert-ryman.aspx</ref> He lives and works in New York.
==Early life and career== Ryman was born in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. After studying at the [[Tennessee Technological University|Tennessee Polytechnic Institute]], Cookeville, between 1948 and 1949, and at the [[George Peabody College for Teachers]] between 1949 and 1950, Ryman enlisted in the United States army reserve corps and was assigned to an army reserve band during the Korean War.<ref name="guggenheimcollection.org">[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_140.html Guggenheim Museum Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026084819/http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_140.html |date=2008-10-26 }}</ref> Ryman moved to [[New York City]] in 1953, intending to become a professional jazz [[saxophonist]]. He had lessons with pianist [[Lennie Tristano]], which later informed his painting.<ref>Colaizzi, Vittorio (Spring 2007) "'How It Works': Stroke, Music, and Minimalism in Robert Ryman's Early Paintings". (Spring 2007) ''American Art''. Vol. 21, No. 1. p. 34.</ref> Ryman soon took a day job at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] as a security guard to make ends meet, and met the artists [[Sol LeWitt]] and [[Dan Flavin]], who were co-workers with him at MoMA. Immediately after quitting his job at MoMA, Ryman spent the next year working in the art division of the [[New York Public Library]]. He also met artist [[Roy Lichtenstein]] during this period of the 1950s.
Captivated by the newly acquired [[abstract expressionist]] works of [[Mark Rothko]], [[Willem de Kooning]], [[Clyfford Still]], [[Jackson Pollock]] and [[Barnett Newman]], Ryman became curious about the act of painting. From 1953 to 1960, he worked at the MoMA as a guard in order to be close to painting.<ref>Phong Bui, "In Conversation: Robert Ryman with Phong Bui" the Brooklyn Rail, June 2007.http://brooklynrail.org/2007/06/art/ryman</ref> He purchased some art supplies at local store and began experimenting in his apartment in 1955. That year, Ryman finished what he considers his earliest professional work, a largely monochrome painting titled ''Untitled (Orange Painting)'' (1955–59).<ref>http://www.diabeacon.org/exhibitions/introduction/94</ref>
Ryman had a close relationship with the late conservator [[Orrin Riley]], who would frequently give him advice on archival materials, many times testing the acidity of media the artist was interested in using. He has been interviewed by the television writer and producer [[Barbaralee Diamonstein]] twice, once for the book and video production ''[[Inside New York's Art World]]'' in 1979 and again for ''Inside the Art World'' in 1993.
In 1961 the artist married art historian [[Lucy Lippard]]. They had a son together, Ethan Ryman, in 1964, who was a sound engineer and recently began making art. This marriage ended in divorce. He later married artist [[Merrill Wagner]].<ref name="guggenheimcollection.org"/> Robert Ryman's sons, [[Cordy Ryman]] and [[Will Ryman]] are also artists and currently work in [[New York City]].
==Work== Ryman is often classified as a [[minimalist]], but he prefers to be known as a "realist" because he is not interested in creating illusions, but only in presenting the materials he has used in compositions at their face value. As he wrote in a statement for a 2010 exhibition at [[Pace Wildenstein]], "I am not a picture painter. I work with real light and space, and since real light is an important aspect of the paintings, it always presents some problems."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Yau|first=John|title=Robert Ryman: Large-small, thick-thin, light reflecting, light absorbing|journal=The Brooklyn Rail|date=March 2010|url=http://brooklynrail.org/2010/03/artseen/robert-ryman-large-small-thick-thin-light-reflecting-light-absorbing}}</ref> The majority of his works feature [[abstract expressionist]]-influenced brushwork in white or off-white paint on square canvas or metal surfaces. A lifelong experimenter with media, Ryman has painted and/or drawn on canvas, [[linen]], steel, aluminum, [[plexiglas]], lumasite, [[Polyvinyl chloride|vinyl]], fiberglass, corrugated paper, [[burlap]], newsprint, wallpaper, [[jute]] sacking, fiberplate, a composite material called [[gator board]], feather board, handmade paper, and [[acrilivin]]. He has used painted and/or drawn with oil, acrylic, encaustic, Lascaux acrylic, [[casein]], enamel, pastel, oil pastel, [[graphite]], [[guache]], and enamelac. Ryman has also experimented with printmaking, creating etchings, [[aquatint]]s, [[lithograph]]s, and silkscreens. His most famous quote is "There is never any question of ''what'' to paint only ''how'' to paint."
By the time Ryman began working, older artists like [[Barnett Newman]], [[Mark Rothko]], and [[Philip Guston]] had already reduced painting to its essences.<ref>[[Roberta Smith]] (1993), [] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> In 1955 Ryman began what he considers his earliest professional work, a largely monochrome painting titled ''Orange Painting'' (1955–59).<ref name="Robert Ryman">[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/show-full/bio/?artist_name=Robert%20Ryman Robert Ryman] Guggenheim Collection.</ref> In the late 1960s he created his ''Classico'' series of compositions consisting of multi-panel paintings on a specific type of paper called Classico. For each work in the series, Ryman attached a configuration of heavy, creamy white sheets of the paper to a wall with masking tape, painted the sheets with a shiny white acrylic paint, removed the tape when the sheets were dry, mounted them on foamcore, and reattached them to the wall. The built-up paint edge tracing the outline of masking tape and the ripped paper left behind give witness to the process of creation. The various works in the Classico series differ in the organization of paper sheets, the configuration of tape traces, and the painted shape.<ref>[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artwork/3745 Robert Ryman, ''Classico IV'' (1968)] Guggenheim Collection.</ref> Just as the ''Classico'' works were titled after the type of paper used as a medium, the so-called ''Surface Veil'' works from 1970 were named for the brand of fiberglass upon which the smaller pieces in this group were painted. Some of the 12-foot square paintings from the series were executed not on fiber-glass but on cotton or linen. In each of these works the pigment appears to form a membrane over the support due to the differing degrees of opacity and translucence in the white paint juxtaposed with areas where less of it has been applied, leaving the fabric exposed. These disruptions in the painting’s skin often mark the literal pauses between the artist’s working sessions.
From 1975 until the late 1990s, Ryman affixed his paintings to the wall with metal brackets. He would design each set of brackets specifically for each piece and have them constructed by a local metals fabricator.
In 2009 he participated in the art project ''Find Me'', by [[Gema Alava]], in company of artists [[Lawrence Weiner]], Merrill Wagner and Paul Kos.<ref name= "findme">{{cite news |last= |first= |url= http://gemaalava.com/work/findme2.htm |title=FIND ME 2.0 |work=[[Gema Alava]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
He has stated that his paintings' titles are meaningless, and that they only exist as a form of identification. Ryman actually prefers the term of "name" for a painting instead of a title because he is not creating a picture or making reference to anything except the paint and the materials. The "names" of paintings often come from the names of art supplies, companies, or are just general words that do not carry much connotation.
==Exhibitions== Ryman had his first one-man show at [[Paul Bianchini]]'s gallery, New York, in 1967 at the age of 36; his first show in Europe came the following year at the Galerie [[Heiner Friedrich]], Munich. One year later, Ryman was included in ''When Attitudes Become Form'', a seminal exhibition of works by Minimalist and Conceptual artists organized by the [[Kunsthalle Bern]].<ref name="guggenheimcollection.org"/> His first one-man show at a museum was in 1972 at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|Guggenheim Museum]] in New York City, displaying thirty-eight of Ryman’s works from 1965 to 1972.<ref name="Robert Ryman"/> Ryman's works were represented in [[documenta]]s 5 (1972), 6 (1977), and 7 (1982), in Kassel, in the [[Venice Biennale]] (1976, 1978, 1980), and in the [[Whitney Biennial]] (1977, 1987, 1995). His first retrospective was organized by the [[Stedelijk Museum]], Amsterdam, in 1974.<ref>[http://www.diabeacon.org/exhibitions/artistbio/94 Robert Ryman] Dia Art Foundation.</ref> In 1992, a major touring retrospective of Ryman's paintings was mounted by the [[Museum of Modern Art]] and the [[Tate Gallery]], including venues such as the [[Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia]] in Madrid, the [[San Francisco Museum of Modern Art]] and the [[Walker Art Center]] in Minneapolis.
Robert Ryman is represented by [[Pace Gallery]] in New York, and [[Xavier Hufkens]] in Brussels.
==Collections== The [[Hallen für Neue Kunst]], a former [[contemporary art]] museum in [[Schaffhausen]], [[Switzerland]] (closed in 2014) had the largest public collection of Ryman's work, permanently exhibiting 29 pieces created from 1959 to 2007. In 2010 Ryman undertook a major reinstallation of his galleries at Hallen für Neue Kunst. Returning to the museum in 2008 — for the first time in 12 years — to revisit the permanent exhibition of his work that was first installed in 1983, he decided to transform the galleries into a “gesamtkunstwerk” — a synthesis, or total experience, composed of 30 paintings from 50 years of work.
In 2017, Ryman donated 21 painting to the [[Dia Art Foundation]]’s permanent collection, making it the only site with an extensive permanent grouping, featuring works made as early as the late 1950s and continuing up to 2003.<ref>Randy Kennedy (April 12, 2017), [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/12/arts/design/robert-ryman-minimalist-master-donates-trove-to-dia-art-foundation.htmlRobert Ryman, Minimalist Master, Donates Trove to Dia Art Foundation] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> Other major museums collecting his works include the [[Museum of Modern Art]], New York; the [[Tate]], London; the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] and the [[Stedelijk Museum]] in Amsterdam.<ref>Randy Kennedy (April 12, 2017), [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/12/arts/design/robert-ryman-minimalist-master-donates-trove-to-dia-art-foundation.htmlRobert Ryman, Minimalist Master, Donates Trove to Dia Art Foundation] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
==Recognition and reception== A recipient of numerous honors, Ryman has been awarded a [[List of Guggenheim Fellowships awarded in 1973|John Simon Guggenheim Foundation Scholarship]] (1973), the Skowhegan Medal from the [[Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture]] (1985).<ref>[http://www.lmgallery.com/artists/robert-ryman/ Robert Ryman] L&M Arts, New York/Los Angeles.</ref> He has been a member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]] since 1994, and assumed the role of the organization’s Vice President in 2003.<ref name="Robert Ryman"/>
In 2005, Ryman was awarded the [[Praemium Imperiale]].
2009 saw the publication of ''Robert Ryman: Critical Texts Since 1967'', edited by Vittorio Colaizzi and [[Karsten Schubert]] and published by [[Ridinghouse]]. The book charts the gradual evolution of the reception of and reaction to Ryman’s art. A comprehensive selection of over 60 essays and exhibition reviews has been collated into one volume, including texts by some of the most influential art historians and critics: [[Yve-Alain Bois]], [[Donald Kuspit|Donald B. Kuspit]], [[Lucy R. Lippard]] and others.
Ryman's painting ''Bridge'' (1980) sold for $20.6 million at a [[Christie's]] auction in 2015.<ref>Randy Kennedy (April 12, 2017), [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/12/arts/design/robert-ryman-minimalist-master-donates-trove-to-dia-art-foundation.htmlRobert Ryman, Minimalist Master, Donates Trove to Dia Art Foundation] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>

Cambridge, MA/London: MIT Press, 1995. * Jean Fremon: ''The Paradoxes of Robert Ryman'', Black Square editions, The Brooklyn Rail, New York, 2008 *Suzanne Hudson, ''Robert Ryman: Used Paint''. {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] | name = The Lord Janvrin | honorific-suffix = {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|GCB|GCVO|QSO}} | image = | order =[[Private Secretary to the Sovereign]] | term_start = 1999 | term_end = 2007 | monarch = [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] | predecessor = Sir [[Robert Fellowes, Baron Fellowes|Robert Fellowes]] | successor = Sir [[Christopher Geidt]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|09|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Cheltenham]], [[Gloucestershire]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | party = | religion = | alma_mater = [[Britannia Royal Naval College]] and [[Brasenose College, Oxford]] | spouse = Isabelle de Boissonneaux de Chevigny }}
'''Robin Berry Janvrin, Baron Janvrin''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCB|GCVO|QSO|PC}} (born 20 September 1946 in [[Cheltenham]]) was the [[Private Secretary to the Sovereign|Private Secretary]] to [[Elizabeth II]] from February 1999 to September 2007.
==Early life== A native of [[Gloucestershire]], Robin Berry Janvrin is the son of [[Vice-Admiral]] Sir [[Richard Janvrin|Hugh Richard Benest Janvrin]] and Nancy Edyth Fielding. He was educated at [[Marlborough College]], [[Britannia Royal Naval College]], [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]], and [[Brasenose College, Oxford]] from which he received a [[British undergraduate degree classification|first class]] [[Bachelor of Arts|bachelor's]] degree in 1969, and of which he was made an Honorary Fellow in 1999. In 1962, he was selected to attend [[Camp Rising Sun (New York)|Camp Rising Sun]] in upstate New York.
==Career== Janvrin entered the [[Royal Navy]] in 1964, was commissioned as an acting sub-lieutenant on 1 September 1966,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=44661|pages=9347–9348|date=27 August 1968}}</ref> promoted [[lieutenant]] on 4 March 1971,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=45454|page=9185|date=24 August 1971}}</ref> and served until 2 July 1975.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=46638|page=9320|date=21 July 1975}}</ref> He subsequently became a member of the [[Castaways' Club]]. On leaving the Navy, Janvrin joined the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]]. He was a [[Second Secretary]] in 1975 and was appointed [[Diplomatic rank|First Secretary]] at the mission to [[NATO]] in 1976. He was officially appointed an Officer of the Diplomatic Service on 7 February 1979.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=47811|page=4500|date=5 April 1979}}</ref> Janvrin was First Secretary in [[New Delhi]] from 1981 to 1984, during which time he was made a Member of the 4th Class of the [[Royal Victorian Order]]<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=49569|page=16478|date=13 December 1983}} Membership of the 4th Class was subsequently renamed so members of this grade became Lieutenants of the order, and were entitled to the [[postnominals]] LVO.</ref> for services during the [[state visit]] by The Queen to [[India]].
Janvrin was then [[Consul (representative)|Counsellor]] and Deputy Head of Department for the Personnel Department of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office from 1985 to 1987.
On 1 June 1987 he was recruited as [[Press Secretary]] to The Queen,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=50942|page=7387|date=9 June 1987}}</ref> though it was initially thought that he would be appointed Assistant Press Secretary. On 19 October 1990 he became Assistant [[Private Secretary]] to The Queen,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=52306|page=16315|date=19 October 1990}}</ref> and in 1996 the Deputy Private Secretary. He was promoted to Commander of the Royal Victorian Order (CVO) in the 1994 [[New Year Honours]],<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=53527|page=4|date=30 December 1993}}</ref> and Knight Commander (KCVO) in the 1998 New Year Honours,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=54993|supp=y|page=3|date=30 December 1997}}</ref> and was appointed a Companion of the [[Order of the Bath]] (CB) in the 1997 New Year Honours.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=54625|supp=y|page=3|date=30 December 1996}}</ref> In February 1999 he succeeded [[Robert Fellowes, Baron Fellowes|Sir Robert Fellowes]] (later Lord Fellowes) as [[Private Secretary to the Sovereign|Private Secretary to the Queen]]. He was promoted to Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath (KCB) in the 2003 New Year Honours.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=56797|supp=y |page=2|date=31 December 2002}}</ref>
Janvrin was also a Trustee of the Queen's 80th Birthday Trust<ref>[http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/ShowCharity/RegisterOfCharities/ContactAndTrustees.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1113063&SubsidiaryNumber=0&TID=3173407&AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1 Trustee, Queen's 80th Birthday Trust]</ref> and is the chairman of trustees of [[The Royal Foundation of The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry]].
In December 2006, it was announced that he would retire in September 2007, to be replaced by [[Christopher Geidt]].<ref name="Buckingham Palace 2006">{{cite press release |title= Announcement of the retirement of Sir Robin Janvrin |publisher= Buckingham Palace |date= 2006-12-19 |url= http://www.royal.gov.uk/output/Page5721.asp |accessdate=2007-01-04 }}</ref> He was promoted to Knight Grand Cross of the [[Order of the Bath]] (GCB) in the 2007 [[Queen's Birthday Honours]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=58358|supp=y |page=2|date=16 June 2007}}</ref> On 24 July 2007, it was announced that Janvrin would be made a [[life peer]], as one of the ten public servants whom the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] may nominate for a peerage, upon their retirement, per Parliament.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.number-10.gov.uk/output/Page12594.asp |title = Announcement of Janvrin's life peerage nomination for service as Private Secretary to the Queen |publisher = 'Number 10' website |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926220431/http://www.number-10.gov.uk/output/Page12594.asp |archivedate = 26 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} </ref><ref>{{London Gazette|issue=58411 |page=11251|date=3 August 2007}}</ref> His title was gazetted as '''Baron Janvrin''', of [[Chalford|Chalford Hill]] in the [[Gloucestershire|County of Gloucestershire]] on 10 October 2007,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=58495 |page=15513|date=26 October 2007}}</ref> and he sits as a [[crossbencher]]. On the day of his retirement, 8 September 2007, Janvrin was promoted to Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order, (GCVO) by The Queen.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=58465 |page=14061|date=28 September 2007}}</ref> In October, The Queen appointed Lord Janvrin to be a [[Lord-in-waiting|Permanent Lord-in-waiting]] in the Royal Household.<ref>''The Times'', 9 September 2007</ref>
In the [[2008 New Year Honours (New Zealand)|2008 New Zealand New Year Honours]], Lord Janvrin was made a Companion of the Queen's Service Order for "services to New Zealand as Private Secretary to The Queen".<ref>[http://www.dpmc.govt.nz/honours/lists/list.asp?id=40 DPMC - New Zealand Honours]</ref>
On 7 January 2008 he took up his appointment of Deputy Chairman, HSBC Private Bank (UK). Janvrin is also Chairman of [[The Leadership Council]], a research and [[thought leadership]] body in the UK.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theleadershipagency.com/the-leadership-council.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025044622/http://www.theleadershipagency.com/the-leadership-council.asp |archivedate=25 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2008, he replaced [[Christopher Mallaby|Sir Christopher Mallaby]] as president of the British [[Entente Cordiale Scholarships|Entente Cordiale Scholarship]] trust.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ambafrance-uk.org/IMG/pdf_100917_EC_Brochure_115x170_pdf_SG.pdf |title = Regards Voices Around the world in seven Entente Cordiale scholars’ stories |publisher = website}} </ref>
==Marriage== He married Isabelle de Boissonneaux de Chevigny, daughter of Yann de Boissonneaux de Chevigny, in 1977.
==In popular culture== Janvrin was portrayed by [[Roger Allam]] in [[Stephen Frears]]' ''[[The Queen (2006 film)|The Queen]]'' (2006) starring [[Academy Awards|Oscar]]-winner [[Helen Mirren|Dame Helen Mirren]]. The film, which deals with the immediate aftermath of the death of [[Diana, Princess of Wales]], in 1997, inaccurately portrays Janvrin, then Deputy Private Secretary to the Sovereign, as Private Secretary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.all-allam.com/film2.html|title=The Queen (2006)|publisher=Roger Allam Films|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref>
==Honours== *'''CB:''' Companion of the Order of the Bath, ''1997'' **'''KCB:''' Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath, ''2003'' ***'''GCB:''' Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath, ''16 June 2007'' *'''LVO:''' Lieutenant of the Royal Victorian Order, ''1983'' (regraded from MVO 4th Class in 1984) **'''CVO:''' Commander of the Royal Victorian Order, ''1994'' ***'''KCVO:''' Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order, ''1998'' ****'''GCVO:''' Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order, ''8 September 2007'' *'''[[Life Peer]]age:''' ''10 October 2007'' *'''QSO:''' Companion of the Queen's Service Order, ''2008'' * '''[[Commemorative Medal for the Centennial of Saskatchewan]]''', ''2005 <ref>[http://www.monarchist.ca/new/docs/honours.html Excerpt from ''The Monarchist'' (Canada)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221034655/http://www.monarchist.ca/new/docs/honours.html |date=21 December 2007 }}</ref> * '''Saskatchewan Distinguished Service Award'''<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110611012444/http://www.gov.sk.ca/news-archive/2005/5/06-400-attachment.pdf Distinguished Service Award to Baron Janvrin by the provincial government of Saskatchewan]</ref>
